На 2 января 8-летний мальчик, Ваня Воронов, был тяжело ранен в его родном городе Шахтерск: его обе ноги и рука были сорваны оболочкой, когда он был во дворе. Были убиты отец мальчика и его младший брат. Ваня получил тяжелые травмы: он потерял обе ноги, руку и ослеп. Нам нужны деньги, чтобы восстановить зрение и для дальнейшего хирургического вмешательства. В настоящее время Ваня находится в России, в НИИ детской хирургии, он должен работать на восстановление зрение в одном глазу, по крайней мере, несколько операций будет сделано с его телом. Мы благодарим вас заранее для вашего пожертвования. Ни один ребенок не должен страдать от войн!

","In May of 2015, Punctuate! Theatre will present the award winning Canadian classic The Suburban Motel Series, and we need your help with the final push!
About The Suburban Motel Series
George F. Walker's The Suburban Motel Series tells six different stories in the same suburban motel room on the north end of Edmonton.
Check out an interview with George F Walker speaking on writing and other productions of The Suburban Motel Series.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b_3Onb_6fTo
About The Project
The Suburban Motel Series is our biggest project to date and we have hired over 40 Edmonton artists to make it happen.
3 directors.
3 assistant directors.
15 actors.
6 designers.
3 stage managers.
3 assistant stage managers.
6 crew members.
1 producer/publicist.
1 technical director.
1 production manager.
24 of those artists are emerging professionals.
The Ask
We are excited that we have the opportunity to work on a project of this size and scope.  However, it does not come without cost.
We are hoping you can help us raise the final $6000 that we need to successfully mount the series.  What does that money go towards, you ask?
$2500 of it goes towards ensuring the actors won't be naked (costume materials).  We need over 30 costumes for the actors.  By donating $84 you could provide and actor with a costume!

$1000  of if goes towards prop materials. By donating you could help us buy any number of things found in a motel room, like a tv, bed, towels, lamps, alarm clock, chairs, a vacuum, tiny vodka bottles- all sorts of fun things!

$2500 of it goes towards construction materials to build the set.  By donating you could help us build walls for the set, buy carpet, source windows and doors so our motel room looks just like it does in real life!
These budgetary requirements are absolutely essential for a professional production.
The Reward

Though our means are little, we believe in offering rewards for any contribution to the show, even if it only takes the form of an acknowledgement in our program. Take a look at the panel on the side for some of the rewards we are happy to provide!
About Punctuate! Theatre

Punctuate! Theatre is a not-for-profit theatre company and a registered charity.  We are an award winning company that has been producing professional independent theatre for the past three years, providing opportunities for early career artists to showcase their work along side seasoned professionals.
The Team
The Directors:  Elizabeth Hobbs (Criminal Genius & Featuring Loretta), Geoffrey Ewert (Adult Entertainment & The End of Civilization), Jeff Page (Problem Child & Risk Everything)
The Assistant Directors:  Harley Morrison (Adult Entertainment & The End of Civilization), Erin Voaklander (Criminal Genius & Featuring Loretta), Patrick Lundeen (Problem Child & Risk Everything)

The Actors: Patrick Howarth, Annette Loiselle, Julien Arnold, Troy O'Donnell, Kristine Nutting, Rebecca Starr, Mark Stubbings, Amber Bissonette, Amber Lewis, Gianna Vacirca, Chris Cook, Neil Kuefler, Oscar Derkx, Elliott James & Andrea Jorawsky
The Designers: Aaron Macri (Sound), Megan Koshka (Set & Costume), Alison Yanota (Lights), Cheyenne Sykes (Costume), Stephanie Bahniuk (Costume)
The Stage Managers: Brooklyn Ritchie (Problem Child & Criminal Genius), Jenn Best (Adult Entertainment & End of Civilization)
The Assistant Stage Managers: Andrea Murphy (Problem Child & Criminal Genius), Erin Hayes (Adult Entertainment & End of Civilization)
The Carpenter/ Light Technician: Maria Burkinshaw
The Producer/ Publicist: Sheiny Satanove
The Associate Producers: Gennieve Edwards & Andrea Jorawsky
The Technical Director: Aaron Wicks

Archiving, Preserving &
column3: >Some years ago while living in my loft in Pilsen, I went to the upper loft to retrieve a tape of an Orchid Show, and what I found were ants: They had invaded and were feasting on all of my tapes. Stunned and not sure what to do, I put the tapes into the freezer to kill the ants, but then I just had cold tapes filled with dead ants. Heart broken, I finally threw them all away. Luckily, Peter Neville who documented most of the Milly shows from it’s beginning at Lounge Ax, made copies of most of the masters before he gave them to me. Some shows are lost forever, but many are still on tape. However, that tape is deteriorating quickly, some of them are well over 25 years old dating back to early 1988. It is, again, my great luck that Peter has become a web-God, and determined to save what we have left (and reduce his clutter), he proposed doing this Indiegogo campaign to archive what remains. I resisted the idea of asking for help, but he was patient, very patient. And then I realized that what has always made the Milly shows great is you, the audience. Performers say it to me over and over again, “You have the best audiences.” So it is fitting that we should do this together as we have always done, because without you, there is no show. Together we will ‘take what God gave us (and the ants haven’t eaten) put a couple a sequins on it’ and get ourselves an archive!

column1: Thank you for it all,
Brigid

","Archiving, Preserving & RestoringSome years ago while living in my loft in Pilsen, I went to the upper loft to retrieve a tape of an Orchid Show, and what I found were ants: They had invaded and were feasting on all of my tapes. Stunned and not sure what to do, I put the tapes into the freezer to kill the ants, but then I just had cold tapes filled with dead ants. Heart broken, I finally threw them all away. Luckily, Peter Neville who documented most of the Milly shows from it’s beginning at Lounge Ax, made copies of most of the masters before he gave them to me. Some shows are lost forever, but many are still on tape. However, that tape is deteriorating quickly, some of them are well over 25 years old dating back to early 1988. It is, again, my great luck that Peter has become a web-God, and determined to save what we have left (and reduce his clutter), he proposed doing this Indiegogo campaign to archive what remains. I resisted the idea of asking for help, but he was patient, very patient. And then I realized that what has always made the Milly shows great is you, the audience. Performers say it to me over and over again, “You have the best audiences.” So it is fitting that we should do this together as we have always done, because without you, there is no show. Together we will ‘take what God gave us (and the ants haven’t eaten) put a couple a sequins on it’ and get ourselves an archive!
Thank you for it all,
Brigid (aka Milly May Smithy) xoxoWhat it would entail is:
Digitizing and archiving of the estimated 30-40 shows (or more).
Restoring some of the poor quality of the older shows.
Building a website to upload and link videos, photos and stories for your viewing pleasure.
How Will It Work?

Digitizing, logging and archiving all of these tapes will be very time consuming. Not to mention, restoring some. The entire project will take over two months, but it will be an ongoing project including additions and uploads of newer shows.

We will have the entire available library of shows digitized and ready for viewing on the website. This would require purchasing domain, hosting, designing and layout of website including uploads and links. In addition, we also need to purchase multiple data storage devices including protective back-ups.
The Impact
Your generous donations will help this project become a reality.
You will be able to view the shows at the website!
See performances you may have missed!
Enjoy hours of entertainment!
View slideshows of photos over the years!
You will get to see:
The first time Blue Man performed in Chicago — when it was just three blue guys igniting our imagination and covering the front rows in bananas and paint—who knew?!
You will also get to see  fabulous performers like:
John ""Sinatra"" Connors
David Sedaris
Eric Bogosian
Frank and Malachy McCourt
Lisa Kron
Syd Straw
Davis Cale
Jim Lauderdale
Poi Dog Pondering
Robert Kline & Karen Valentine
Nora Dunn
Matthew Owens
Paula Killen
Cheyl Trykv
Dennis DeBondt
Monk the Wandering Wizard
PLUS! A variety of variety acts!
and, of course, Consuelo Allen as Milly’s little spoon-danglin' bard-reciting sister, Willy May.
Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount that you contribute will help, but if you’d like to participate in another way,  you could send this campaign to your friend's and family, and help spread the word to other Milly fans. We would also love to see any video or photos you might have to add to the archives. There are still many shows that are missing, and you may have a piece of  Milly-history somewhere.
Don't forget to check back soon as the fun unfolds on the website launching!
Now, give us a twirl, honey!  xoxo  -Milly

portfolio and biography information.  We

2015/2016 admissions.
We humbly seek your support and
contribution towards our creative future with this institution.  Our intension is to raise enough funds to
cover the full tuition amounts or as a second option, the requisite amount for funding
through a banking credit facility.
Your financial investment will
enhance this once-in-a-lifetime experience for us and inevitably contribute
towards the development of St. Lucia’s holistic talent and entertainment
industry.  It is truly our life’s dream
to be qualified in our disciplines in order to make positive contributions to
the youth and economy of our island.
We will be forever grateful for your
support and will remain at your company’s service for participation in events,
programs and workshops upon completion of our courses.
Please feel free to contact us at any
time to discuss the details contained in this proposal.
Respectfully yours,
Co-Founder ONYX Dance Crew    Co-Founder ONYX Dance Crew

childhood involved entertainment of different sorts.  With our regular home shows, we would find

how it all just falls into place.

BIOGRAPHY
We are
sisters Bashana Leah Dayes (29 yrs) and Shadrea Tashi Dayes (27 yrs) who share
a passion for performing arts in dance and theatre, culture and DJ production –
we founded the ONYX Dance Crew.
Our parents
are from St. Lucian and Jamaican roots, they both lived their adult life in the
UK and moved to St. Lucia in 1985 – mother a social worker and event
coordinator, father a store owner and tradesman.  Growing up was very colorful to say the
least giving us opportunities to travel as a family and attend performance
events from an early age.
Our
childhood involved entertainment of different sorts.  With our regular home shows, we would find
any reason to dance and entertain.  Music
always filled the house, when our mother played her vinyl records of Jamaican
reggae, Scar, Lovers’ Rock, Dub etc, our burning passion for music
bubbled.  We’ve enjoyed stage shows like
SLU Jazz Festival through the early 90’s and met some of the international
artistes, Zion Train with local artists, regional shows featuring performers
like Sizzla, Anthony B,  Maxi Priest,
John Holt and so on.  We would be amazed
at the entire production of a show both with talent and hands on for set up,
how it all just falls into place.
We became
members of the Charmolion Dance Ensemble and got our first chances at 15 to
work and perform at hotels, national shows and regional arts festivals.  Bashana played the flute in the Secondary
School Concert Band and Shadrea performed in an independence theatre production
titled ‘Anthem’ while we danced with Ms. Rosemary Etienne.  We both participated in cheerleading
competitions and now choreograph pieces with students from a few schools.  Shadrea’s choreography with Corinth Secondary
School, won the national cheerleading competition in 2004.
Shadrea
danced professionally with choreographer Yalitza Garcia at Club St. Lucia by
Splash which played a major role in developing her stage presence and dance
technique.  Bashana has been a model in
television and print advertising and has walked for renowned designers in a
number of fashion shows.  Most recently
being HOT Couture in our Jazz & Arts Festival 2014.  She also plays a leading role in our local
show series Island Secrets.
Accomplishing
all of this was never easy when time, energy and money didn’t always balance
out so we could fully pursue some of our given opportunities.  Self development and certifying our talent
has been our focus for the past 4 years.
We have ignited this burning desire and have realized creative
expression to be our purpose in life.
Currently, we
host an Urban Dance Fitness class twice a week branded “MOVES 4 DAYES” where we
use Afro beats, Soca, Dancehall & Hip hop dance routines to flex, tone and
Isolate the muscles.  We help young and
mature ladies stay fit while having fun.
Our dreams
are to attend the Edna Manley School of Dance where we can gain more knowledge
of proper techniques in Modern, Contemporary, Folk, African and Dancehall to
work internationally and share our skills with our Country, Community, and
Schools.
Volunteerism
is also very close to our heart.  We work
closely with the Rainbow Bridge Project in Aux Lyons and Prosaf SLU/The Power
of One NGO where we assist with event coordination and community dance classes
for children.  We also perform and
collaborate with smaller community groups e.g. youth group of St. Michael’s
Parish of La Resource Dennery and Aux Lyons Sports Club wherever possible.
Shadrea
Dayes Aka PRINCESS TASHI was a Heineken Green Synergy DJ Finalist in 2014 and
incorporated her dancing creativity to her performance production.  Bashana Aka QUEEN B was her MC and hype
Girl.  Our ultimate goal is to dance and
DJ for a living.  We are no strangers to
hard work and understand that with success comes great study and practice.
We look
forward to an active future in entertainment!
Bless,

Danielle Zuniga and Reyna Mondragon, have been selected as part of the 2016 Fledgling Project produced by The Phoenix Theater and Arts Nest. As choreographers, Zuniga and Mondragon are very diverse. After an audition selection process, they selected fourteen dancers to join them in inspiring their ideas and concepts.  This gives their dancers the opportunity to perform and grow in their abilities and profession. This exposes the community to what these new and upcoming artist have to offer the Twin Cities and the modern dance culture. Their show entitled Altered Odyssey will be an evening filled with dance and exploration that will infuse the minds of the audience with an intrinsic insight to modern dance.
<b>Danielle Zuniga
and Reyna Mondragon both graduated from the University of North Texas
with Bachelors of Fine Arts in Dance.  As choreographers they have
individually had works adjudicated at the American Collegiate Dance
Conference. They are currently producing a self-portrait show,

was also a part of Mad Minute Films. As she continues to explore the

the completion of this concert, Reyna Mondragon will be continuing
her education by pursing her Masters of Fine Arts in Dance at Texas
Woman’s University. After moving to the Twin Cities, Danielle
Zuniga has begun working with Black Label Movement as an assistant
and dancer. Zuniga performed in Four

is currently assisting and will be performing with BLM’s TV

Zuniga and Reyna Mondragon are both passionate about starting their
careers as professional dancers and excited about the opportunities
to come.

","Danielle Zuniga and Reyna Mondragon, have been selected as part of the 2016 Fledgling Project produced by The Phoenix Theater and Arts Nest. As choreographers, Zuniga and Mondragon are very diverse. After an audition selection process, they selected fourteen dancers to join them in inspiring their ideas and concepts.  This gives their dancers the opportunity to perform and grow in their abilities and profession. This exposes the community to what these new and upcoming artist have to offer the Twin Cities and the modern dance culture. Their show entitled Altered Odyssey will be an evening filled with dance and exploration that will infuse the minds of the audience with an intrinsic insight to modern dance.

Bugs

Bugs are crawling on your skin. In the night, you feel them in your bed sheets, crawling around, laying their eggs. You wake up to a deafening sound in your ear. The bugs are burrowing into your head. They're everywhere. You're infested.
Bug by Tracy Letts is an extraordinary horror play about the complicated and frightening nature of mental illness and how anyone living just on the edge can be pushed over with a gentle nudge.

Agnes lives alone in a shabby motel room. Her ex-husband has been recently released from prison, she is receiving ominous phone calls with only breathing on the other end, and her best friend has brought over a socially awkward stranger. This mysterious man claims that her motel room is infested with bugs. Is it? She is sick of living in constant fear, but to what lengths will she go to free herself from suffering? Will she believe anything he tells her?

The horror genre has been tragically underrepresented on stage. Bug is a perfect example of a legitimate horror experience that is both challenging and scary. This tragic tale of grief can be brought to life with your help. Help my team and I bring horror to the stage.
Cast:
Agnes: Jasmine Castronuovo
Peter: Nicholas Tyler Corbin
Goss: Myles Clohessy
R.C: Melina Finck
Dr. Sweet: Jeffrey Weisz
Production Team (So Far):
Director/Producer: Ethan Steers
Stage Manager: Jessica Rappaport
Sound Designer: Kevin Downing
Dates:

Performances: April 28th, 29th, and 30th

What We Need

The most important element to a horror experience is atmosphere. We will need all the money we can get in order to transport our audience to Agnes' motel room.
Lighting
Since we are not putting up this play in a traditional space, the lighting will have to be unconventional. We will be using lamps as well as LED bug lights. Each of these cost around $40 each.
Sound

In order to create the intense mood that Bug requires, we will need to rent sound equipment. This will ensure that the audience feels that they are inside the mind of the characters, hearing what they hear.
Set
The more money we receive, the better our set will look. We need a full size bed, a couch, a refrigerator, a coffee table, and a tarp.
Blood
This play has blood. People die. People get hurt. In order to create the realistic special effects this play requires, we will need to purchase gallons of stage blood. Each gallon is about $20.
Tin Foil

Toward the end of the play, the motel room becomes completely covered with tin foil. I don't want to spoil the story, but this is absolutely essential to the plot. Industrial strength tin foil runs about $25 per roll and we expect to need as many of these as we can get.
Rights
Lastly, in order to produce this play, we have to pay for the rights. The total cost is $240. Without it, we can't put up the show!
Your generosity will not go unrewarded. On the right side of the page, you will find the various perks you will receive based on the size of your donation.
WHY BUG IS IMPORTANT RIGHT NOW
<div>
<div>

In a horror story, the horror elements are only there to service the character development and to better enlighten the audience on what the storyteller is trying to say. A ghost story is never about the ghost. It is about the people being haunted.

The characters in Bug are haunted by their own minds, and the horror elements in Tracy Lett's play are there to service the discussion of how intense grief can contribute to the development of mental illness. Discussing mental illness and what leads to it is an important discussion in our society today.
<div>
<div>
<h3>Risks &amp
column2:
Challenges

Our greatest challenge in putting up this play is to ensure that the difficult subject matter is handled with respect and integrity. In order for this to be done, we will need your help. With proper lighting, sound, and effects, Tracy Lett's play can shine the way it was always meant to.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are always other ways that you can help our production out. Please share the page! Get the word out about this production, and if you know of anyone you think would be into a play like this, send them the link!
If you have any questions, please email:
bugproductionteam@gmail.com
Thank you for your contribution!
Sincerely,
Ethan Steers,

column3: >Tirelessly Chasing Sincerity Without Irony  |  Embracing Hope Fearlessly
column6:
> 

About Our First Show

The Only Goal That Ever Matters to Any Running Boy

A New Play by Zach Rufa | Directed by Alex Keegan

Presented by Dixon Place |  Jan 29th, 2016

The football field at midnight in late August. It's a bright night. Up this far North, every night is well lit, twinkling with the light of more stars in the sky than you're probably ever seen. On the field, Jace waits for Evan. After 18 years, they have one final night together before an inevitable goodbye. Sometimes, the most haunting ghosts are just those of the people we used to be.

 

Tickets are: $12 in advance, $15 at the door, $10 students/seniors  and are available for purchase by clicking HERE

A little bit about us...
<span style=""font-size: 16px
column6: Flow Productions is a burgeoning bespoke theatre company founded by Chelsey Ng based in New York City. We aim to curate theatrical experiences that foster visceral connections between the audience and the actor.

column1: 'Danny and the Deep Blue Sea' has been a labor of love for the past year. It's been a journey of experimentation and it continues to be a constantly evolving beast. There has never been a dull moment in our rehearsal space which is exciting because the production continues to breathe and live with each step we take moving forward.
About the director...
My name is Chelsey Ng and I hail from the sunny island of Singapore. I moved to the glorious, glittering, all consuming island of Manhattan in the Fall of 2013 and have made a home for myself here.

What I've discovered on this whirlwind of a creative journey is that I'm happiest when I am creating in any way shape or form. I fully intend on constantly exploring new mediums and I have no intention of stopping that process anytime soon.
The decision to take on 'Danny' was, like most good things in life, spontaneous. I was having drinks with my best friends (Sam &
column2: Monty - AKA the cast) , we had just wrapped ""D I S T O R T I O N"" (an experimental variety show we worked on in the Spring of last year) and were kind of in a daze. We knew we had captured magic in the little scene we had explored from 'Danny' and we didn't know how to let it go.

column1: So we didn't.
We took it upon ourselves to dive headfirst into the murky glorious depths of Shanley's masterpiece because we knew no one else would do it for us.

It's honestly been terrifying but it's also been enormously liberating to see this production take shape. To know that creating your own work truly isn't impossible, all it takes is vision, drive and belief.
Oh... and of course, I would be lost amidst the mire if it weren't for the support of beautiful people like you.
What We Need
We've set a goal of $2500 to bolster our production value.
<ul>
<li>

$1500: Scenic Design.

Without spoiling all the fun, the scenic design of 'Danny' is incredibly ambitious and essential to the world of the play. Audience members will be transported into a heightened world, unlike any they would associate with previous interpretations of this work.

This unique multi-sensory performance will take place in a former knitting factory/butchery/underground artist gallery that has been reimagined as a multi-purpose raw space called the Artery @464 Seneca Avenue in Brooklyn, New York.

There will be many tactile elements such as sand and driftwood. Large billowy sheets of muslin. Crushed rose petals. Paper lanterns. Anchors and so on.

We understand that this is incredibly ambiguous - but half the fun is in the mystery, isn't it?

We promise to engage all five sense throughout the evening in various cheeky ways.
<ul>
<li>
$1000: Theatrical Gastronomy.
column2:
>
As mentioned, we want to engage all 5 senses and one of the most powerful senses we have is taste.

column1:
For one of our perks (Evening on the Deck) we invite a select few to partake in an evening of epicurean delight.  A stunning four course representation of the world in which our characters live.

Another one of our perks involves a selection of delectable canapé's and bespoke cocktails catered to your desires. 

We've always found that creating an event out of any theatrical experience allows for audience members to have a platform for catharsis and discussion.

What better way to encourage conversation than with a little liquid courage?
Perks!
<ul>
<li>
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column4: >You and a guest are invited to a one of a kind dining experience with the cast and creative team on the set before the doors open. Prepare yourself for bespoke cuisine and cocktails inspired by the show and discussions with the creative team.

Riptide
$75: A shout out in the playbill signed by the cast and creative team, a ticket to a night of your choice, a drink on us, a  limited edition print of the 'Danny' poster signed by the cast and creative team AND your choice of a limited edition print of TWO of these beautiful 'Danny' inspired photographs shot by the amazing Boon Chian (follow the link below).
http://imgur.com/a/VdcuY
<li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2:
>Tidal Wave
$100: A shout out in the playbill signed by the cast and creative team, a ticket to a night of your choice, a drink on us, a  limited edition print of the 'Danny' poster signed by the cast and creative team AND your choice of a limited edition print of THREE of these beautiful 'Danny' inspired photographs shot by the amazing Boon Chian (follow the link below).
http://imgur.com/a/VdcuY

column1: <li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2:
>Scene Stealer

$125: A shout out in the playbill signed by the cast and creative team, a ticket to a night of your choice, a drink on us, a limited edition print of the Danny poster signed by the cast and creative team AND a one of a kind illustration drawn during the performance by incredibly talented Clay Rodery which you'll walk away with that very night.

column1: Impact You're Making
There would be no progress without experimentation. With 'Danny' we've taken great liberties with the form in which we're presenting this beautifully simple expression of humanity.

As a company we want to take storytelling to more intimate depths, we want you to walk away feeling like you've been privy to something that you maybe shouldn't have been. You will have a story to tell that is entirely yours and that you could only share with those who were with you in that room.
By supporting us you'll be helping us to more fully flesh out a world for our actors to live in and for you to be a part of.

Word of Mouth...

If you aren't in a position to contribute, don't fret! There are still ways you can help us out.

Share and like Ebb&

column1: ","A little bit about us...

Ebb&Flow Productions is a burgeoning bespoke theatre company founded by Chelsey Ng based in New York City. We aim to curate theatrical experiences that foster visceral connections between the audience and the actor.

'Danny and the Deep Blue Sea' has been a labor of love for the past year. It's been a journey of experimentation and it continues to be a constantly evolving beast. There has never been a dull moment in our rehearsal space which is exciting because the production continues to breathe and live with each step we take moving forward.
About the director...
My name is Chelsey Ng and I hail from the sunny island of Singapore. I moved to the glorious, glittering, all consuming island of Manhattan in the Fall of 2013 and have made a home for myself here.

The decision to take on 'Danny' was, like most good things in life, spontaneous. I was having drinks with my best friends (Sam & Monty - AKA the cast) , we had just wrapped ""D I S T O R T I O N"" (an experimental variety show we worked on in the Spring of last year) and were kind of in a daze. We knew we had captured magic in the little scene we had explored from 'Danny' and we didn't know how to let it go.
So we didn't.
We took it upon ourselves to dive headfirst into the murky glorious depths of Shanley's masterpiece because we knew no one else would do it for us.

It's honestly been terrifying but it's also been enormously liberating to see this production take shape. To know that creating your own work truly isn't impossible, all it takes is vision, drive and belief.
Oh... and of course, I would be lost amidst the mire if it weren't for the support of beautiful people like you.

We've set a goal of $2500 to bolster our production value.

Large billowy sheets of muslin. Crushed rose petals. Paper lanterns. Anchors and so on.We understand that this is incredibly ambiguous - but half the fun is in the mystery, isn't it?We promise to engage all five sense throughout the evening in various cheeky ways.

Gaston School of the Arts (GSOA) is a
non-profit 501(C)(3) community school for the arts founded in 1986, that
provides affordable education in music, visual arts, and drama for local
children and adults. GSOA provides individual
instruction in piano, woodwinds, violin, banjo, mandolin, guitar, brass, percussion
and voice throughout the year. Current community enrollment in these programs
is slightly above 200 students! The School also offers group instruction for
children in visual arts and drama during the school year
camps in drama, music and visual art for grades K-12. The GSOA Youth Orchestra
offers young people a chance to learn the art of ensemble instrument playing
and increase their proficiency on their instrument. <span>The School’s children’s theatre,<span>GSOA
Playhouseprovides local
young people performance and educational opportunities in all of the theatrical
arts. Recently we have expanded our music program to include The Bluegrass
Music Project, which is a collaborative effort to explore and preserve North
Carolina’s deep-rooted traditional music.
. GSOA charges a minimum fee that varies by program
and only covers the operating cost of the programs, with a built in allowance for
need based scholarships. GSOA believes that nothing should hold a person back
from pursuing an education in the fine arts, especially their economic
situation.<span>  We are funded by a
combination of tuition payments, private donations and corporate sponsorships.
Our funding is distributed firstly to operating costs, which are kept to minimum,
equipment necessary for classes, and providing tuition assistance to those who
need it. Because of this we have an ever-growing number of very talented and
ambitious students who enjoy performing for their community. However our dedication
to community involvement and our mission of ensuring that every student that desires
an artistic education is able to participate, has left us with a budget
shortfall. We have thus far been unable to secure funding for equipment that is
essential for our students to perform for the community. We have an amazing
stage and auditorium, however we do not have any audio projection, processing,
or amplification equipment. We are seeking donations in any amount so that we
can purchase audio equipment that will allow our performers to showcase their
various talents. We need four speakers, microphones, and wires/connectors to
make the system work. Our goal is to raise $2,000 by June 26<sup>th</sup> 2015
so that we can utilize our new system in the summer performance of Into the
Woods, not to mention future performances of the 2015/2016 season.
In the spirit of transparency we will distribute any money
raised above our fundraising goal as outlined below.
Scholarship
funding: 35%
Future
script purchasing 25%
On
average it cost $1,500 to purchase the rights to legally perform a play or musical
Future
production cost 60%
This
rather broad category includes costumes, song books, building materials for
sets, additional script copies for cast members, liability insurance (you know
to keep the kiddos safe), building permits and inspection cost, life and fire
safety, accessibility, advertisement, and really an endless list of items that are
required to legally and safely produce a show.
What’s in it for you? Firstly you will receive that
wonderful, warm and fuzzy feeling associated with acts of kindness that have a
profound and lasting impact on children’s futures. Secondly, and if you want a
more substantial reflection of your kindness, anyone who makes a single
contribution of $100.00 will have their name appear on the donors page in the
programs for this seasons performances. Anyone who makes a single contribution
of $150.00 will have a full page in the program that can be used for any approved advertisement, in
memoriam, dedicated to, or in honor of, submission. A copy of that program,
signed by the cast will be mailed to you after the performance. Anyone who
makes a single contribution of $200 or more will have their name placed on a
sponsorship plaque located on the sound/lighting booth.<span>  Anyone who makes a single contribution of
$1,000,000 or more will have a non-profit community school for the arts named
after them! Seriously, all donations
in any amount are very much
appreciated, no matter how large or small the donation it will make a difference!
Thank you for taking the time to consider making a
donation to GSOA. If you are not able to make a donation right now please
bookmark this page as our fund drive will be open for a month. Every donation
counts and can be used so please take a quick moment to share information about
our cause on social media, the more exposure we have the better our chances of
meeting our fundraising goal.

What / Who is Daggers MacKenzie?

Daggers MacKenzie is a one-woman musical about a knife juggler who runs away from a circus in 1894. I perform as different characters, sing original songs, and throw sharp metal near my face in the service of a story about love, risk, power dynamics, and finding your home.

The character originally came to me in a dream at a time when I was playing guitar, singing, and writing songs in bands, something I've been doing since I was a teenager. I wanted to go deeper with what I could do and create a real performance. I'm absolutely crazy about Hedwig and the Angry Inch (I was Yitzhak for a show when I was just out of college) and I also love Kate Bush and the way she immerses herself in different characters through song.

I started writing the music and let that tell me what the story was about, and decided I would embody the characters. I did that soul-searching thing that artists do and discovered that Daggers was a knife juggler, but I didn't know how to juggle. So I started training with professional jugglers and developing skills -- which I still do daily. It's frustrating and fun and totally worth it.

I recorded the music with producer Michael Eisenstein (Letters to Cleo), who worked extensively with my band in the past and was pivotal to creating the music. I then began developing the show with director Stephanie Abrams, founder of LA circus school Kinetic Theory Circus Arts and Theatre, who really helped make a bulk of this possible by contributing her resources, expertise, and theatre. We staged the show with a full band at the theatre last year, and it was incredible.

The process, from dream to development to implementation, took me three years, and the time, support, patience, and dedication of friends. I'm grateful. And I want to honor everyone's time by growing the show's audience and my performance skills and taking it to the next level.
This is year four, and I'm taking the show on tour to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and the United Solo Festival in NYC. I've got a great team behind me, and we're ready to go.
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

Up until this point, I've covered much of the hard cash stuff on my own -- recordings, promotion, airfare and fees. The cost of taking a show overseas is enormous, and I've covered some already, but there are a few more things we still need to cover.

I've covered the cost of flights and the deposit to the theatre. This is what we still need (some costs converted to U.S. dollars from British pounds):

  • Hotel (reserved, not yet paid): $2,883 for two people for 18 days. That's $160 each day, which is a good rate for a big city during festival season.
• Food / expenses for two people for 18 days in Edinburgh (includes haggis): $900. That's $25 per person, per day, or roughly £16.5.
• Round-trip flight from LA to NYC, plus baggage (I can't board with knives): $380
• Promotion for Edinburgh: $180 for 5,000 flyers, 100 posters, and shipping to the venue
• Promotion for NYC: $150 for flyers and posters
• CD booklets: $80 for 200 prints (see an example in the gallery -- we fold and glue them!)
• Edinburgh performer's Insurance (everyone at the festival needs this, whether they're juggling knives in front of an audience or just speaking very loudly at them): $120
• Two Edinburgh bus passes: $135
• Shipping and handling of Indiegogo perks: $40
<div>These are the basics. Daggers is a show with incredibly low overhead, and anything my director and I can do ourselves, we do. Any extra money we make will help us grow the show
column2: we'd love to hire a videographer and promoter, pay for more ads, create merchandise (CDs, CD booklets, posters, t-shirts), improve upon our costumes and props, hire another band and record more music.

column1: The perks come straight from the skills cultivated to create the show: I will sing you songs, share my songwriting, guitar and juggling knowledge, entice you with character work, perform for you live or over Skype, and basically lay my heart bare. This is part of the work I want to accomplish in the show anyway, so if I get a chance to rattle your emotions and leave you with something that makes you feel or think anything, I've done my job.
The Impact
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >There's a reason this show took me three years to launch. I wanted to create a quality experience so badly that I trained new skills, sought out a team of professionals, and saved up money to make this the best show I possibly could. And through the process of bringing this show public I continue to find ways to make the experience even better.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >I want this to be a moving experience for anyone who watches it, no matter what your tastes.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Here's a review from arts and music blog The Indie Handbook:

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
“What
does a one-woman lesbian circus indie pop-rock opera look like? Corsets, cowboy
boots, and yes, actual knife juggling all play a role in what adds up to a
compelling and often genuinely funny drama about love, crime, and sexual
awakening. But none
of it would be possible without Kaplan’s knack for narrative
songwriting. Whether it’s the alt-country lead single, ‘All Aboard,’ the
seduction ballad ‘I Feel Good,’ or the climactic belter ‘The Love Reprimand,’
strong  melodies are the thread that ties
the whole set – the whole show – together.”
<div>
<span style=""background-color: initial
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
For one, we need a roof over our head in Edinburgh!

Beyond that, this campaign took a lot of planning, and now we have momentum going. Edinburgh is the largest arts festival in the world, and it's wonderful and daunting and requires constant work and promotion. It's not enough just to go there and do the show -- we want people to see it, and that means hitting the streets and flyering, meeting new people every day to get the word out, being engaged and making people care.

<div>The show doesn't start when we enter the theatre, but when we hit the streets. My director and I will be talking and singing and miming in alleys and squares, in parks and near store fronts, all to grab some ears and eyes and get people to come. <span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >We just need flyers and a hearty Scottish breakfast.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

The most immediate thing you can do is share this link -- especially with a handful of friends you know will be interested.
Otherwise: Come to the shows! If you're in Edinburgh, LA or NYC or know people who are, please consider coming to a performance.
The LA preview show is Saturday, 7/11, 8 pm at Kinetic Theory. Buy tickets here (bottom right of the page):
http://www.kinetictheorytheatre.com

column5: >And here are details for the Edinburgh show, running 8/16 through 8/31 at Spotlites Theatre:

column1: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/daggers-mackenzie
And tickets for the United Solo Festival in NYC on 11/6:
http://unitedsolo.org/us/daggersmackenzie-2015/

column5: >I'm also open to working with knowledgable professionals willing to donate their time and skills: promoters, technicians, designers, photographers, bookers, anyone who has worked on a theatre or music campaign before, is excited about the show and knows the ropes.

column1: Finally, follow us on any social media. I'll be blogging and posting pictures throughout the experience and would love your comments. Let me know you're here!
THANK YOU.

What We Need & What You Get

The Impact

There's a reason this show took me three years to launch. I wanted to create a quality experience so badly that I trained new skills, sought out a team of professionals, and saved up money to make this the best show I possibly could. And through the process of bringing this show public I continue to find ways to make the experience even better.
I want this to be a moving experience for anyone who watches it, no matter what your tastes.
Here's a review from arts and music blog The Indie Handbook:
“What
does a one-woman lesbian circus indie pop-rock opera look like? Corsets, cowboy
boots, and yes, actual knife juggling all play a role in what adds up to a
compelling and often genuinely funny drama about love, crime, and sexual

More: https://theindiehandbook.wordpress.com/2015/04/01/daggers-mackenzie-knife-juggler-outlaw/
Risks & Challenges
For one, we need a roof over our head in Edinburgh!

Beyond that, this campaign took a lot of planning, and now we have momentum going. Edinburgh is the largest arts festival in the world, and it's wonderful and daunting and requires constant work and promotion. It's not enough just to go there and do the show -- we want people to see it, and that means hitting the streets and flyering, meeting new people every day to get the word out, being engaged and making people care.

The show doesn't start when we enter the theatre, but when we hit the streets. My director and I will be talking and singing and miming in alleys and squares, in parks and near store fronts, all to grab some ears and eyes and get people to come. We just need flyers and a hearty Scottish breakfast.

I'm also open to working with knowledgable professionals willing to donate their time and skills: promoters, technicians, designers, photographers, bookers, anyone who has worked on a theatre or music campaign before, is excited about the show and knows the ropes.

WHO WE ARE
column2:
>We are Harry Blake and Alice Keedwell. Together we are HOUSE OF BLAKEWELL - every festival’s favourite cabaret / comedy / music-and-dance duo. 
Winner: Craig Barbour Award for Songwriting (Soho Theatre)
column3: >Winner: Pick of the Fringe (VAULT Festival 2014)
column4: >Winner: Pick of the Week (VAULT Festival 2015)

column2: >You can watch the trailer for the show here.

column1: WHAT WE’RE DOING
column2: >WE CAN MAKE YOU HAPPY is our third full show, created with the support of Arts Council England. We’ve performed the show to packed-out houses in London, Brighton and beyond, and have made a lot of people happy. We’re really proud of the show, and have been offered the fantastic opportunity to bring musical joy to the wet and windy EDINBURGH FRINGE FESTIVAL this summer. We will be performing in Assembly’s Bosco tent in George Square Gardens with a whopping 180 seats to fill each afternoon for a month. We’re working with a dream creative team, and are ready to showcase our work to programmers and producers from all over the world, but first… we need your help!

column1: WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP
column2: >So far, we have raised £8,000 towards our Edinburgh adventure, including £4,000 from the BBC Performing Arts Fund. We now need just £2,500 to get us across the border, and that’s where you come in.

column1: Although money can’t buy happiness, here’s a look at what it can buy:
<ul>
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >£10 = 80 minutes of flyering by our fantastic street team

column1: <li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >£25 =  the fee for one performance by our sound operator, or a whole family of gnomes to fill the stage and keep us company

column1: <li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >£50 = a month’s supply of helium to keep us, and our balloons, buoyant at all times

column1: <li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >£100 = hygiene - new costumes for Harry and Alice, which will allow them to change their clothes occasionally

column1: <li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >£500 = one week’s accommodation at the Fringe, or one payment to our wonderful press rep

column1: THE HAPPY ENDING

With your help, we will not only make Edinburgh happy, but will also be able to make the very most of this showcase opportunity, pay our professional team the fees they deserve, and ensure a future life for the show.
THANK YOU

","WHO WE AREWe are Harry Blake and Alice Keedwell. Together we are HOUSE OF BLAKEWELL - every festival’s favourite cabaret / comedy / music-and-dance duo. Winner: Craig Barbour Award for Songwriting (Soho Theatre)Winner: Pick of the Fringe (VAULT Festival 2014)Winner: Pick of the Week (VAULT Festival 2015)Finalist: People’s Choice Award (VAULT Festival 2015)
You can watch the trailer for the show here.

WHAT WE’RE DOINGWE CAN MAKE YOU HAPPY is our third full show, created with the support of Arts Council England. We’ve performed the show to packed-out houses in London, Brighton and beyond, and have made a lot of people happy. We’re really proud of the show, and have been offered the fantastic opportunity to bring musical joy to the wet and windy EDINBURGH FRINGE FESTIVAL this summer. We will be performing in Assembly’s Bosco tent in George Square Gardens with a whopping 180 seats to fill each afternoon for a month. We’re working with a dream creative team, and are ready to showcase our work to programmers and producers from all over the world, but first… we need your help!

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELPSo far, we have raised £8,000 towards our Edinburgh adventure, including £4,000 from the BBC Performing Arts Fund. We now need just £2,500 to get us across the border, and that’s where you come in.
Although money can’t buy happiness, here’s a look at what it can buy:
£10 = 80 minutes of flyering by our fantastic street team
£25 =  the fee for one performance by our sound operator, or a whole family of gnomes to fill the stage and keep us company
£50 = a month’s supply of helium to keep us, and our balloons, buoyant at all times
£100 = hygiene - new costumes for Harry and Alice, which will allow them to change their clothes occasionally
£500 = one week’s accommodation at the Fringe, or one payment to our wonderful press rep
THE HAPPY ENDING

With your help, we will not only make Edinburgh happy, but will also be able to make the very most of this showcase opportunity, pay our professional team the fees they deserve, and ensure a future life for the show.
THANK YOU

Short Summary

PechaKucha + , Jim Madden and Ryan Cassavaugh are bringing master puppeteer, Dan Hurlin to Bozeman to screen the film, PUPPET (74 min.) and to conduct a puppet workshop. Film with Q. and A. on Friday evening, Sept. 25th and Workshop on Saturday afternoon, Sept. 26th. 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

The total cost for these two events is $ 2,500.

column1: PechaKucha + will generously donate $1,000, MSU School of Art will donate $200, and we need to raise the balance of the funds.
Donations of any amount, large or small, are graciously appreciated and with your help we will make this happen. Check out the perk benefits too !

Dan Hurlin teaches theatre at Sarah Lawrence College and has won wide acclaim for his work with puppets, including a Rome Prize in 2013. Dan brings puppets to life in a most captivating and engaging way. His knowledge and mastery of this story-telling medium brought to Bozeman will energize both the theatre and arts communities, and the community at large.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell ALL of your friends about the film screening and the workshop. Get the word out and make some noise !!!  That will really help us publicize this unique opportunity for our town.
Come to PechaKucha # 16 at the Ellen Theatre / Sept. 15 &
column2: 16                                      Get your tickets early @ www.theellentheatre.com

column1: Sadie Cassavaugh will be doing a P-K presentation about her work with puppets !

<h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
column4:
>LADY is a new play about the lengths we go to for beauty and power. It's loosely based on Countess Bathory, who (if the rumors are true) killed over 600 young girls making her the worst serial killer in history. LADY and our team were chosen for the 2015 Araca Project and the play will have six performances at the American Theatre of Actors from October 28th-November 1st.
  • Hi, I'm Sofya, and I am the executive producer and playwright of this project. I have a history of self-producing, from high school to my theatre major studies at Loyola Marymount University. I recently graduated with my MFA in playwriting and screenwriting from Northwestern University, where I produced the quarterly MasterClash! reading series, and was commissioned by Steep Theatre to write a new play.
column5: >This is a fast and furious campaign in which we hope to raise more funds to put towards the investment from the Araca Project and a grant from Northwestern. This last piece of contribution will be instrumental in renting rehearsal space, getting important set pieces (i.e. a bathtub), paying our devoted artists who are offering up a month or their dedicated time, and lighting and sound packages to make this a polished, beautiful and thrilling piece of theatre.

column1: <li>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Your donations will not only help us put on an incredibly effective, bold and beautiful show, but you will help ensure the future life of this production and help me make an impact on the theatrical world of New York City.

column1:
If you can't make it out to see the show, consider donating to help us make our dreams for this production and its future life in New York City. Be a part of something important and meaningful.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

This is what your donation will ensure:

  • On this campaign, we are asking for $1500, a smaller sum for a production of this scale but that would be imperative towards rehearsal space rental, important set pieces, payment of our artists, and lighting packages.
  • We're offering free tickets to our New York City show, free refreshments during the production, unique pieces of production art, producing credits and other exciting perks.

The Team

column1: We are so excited about our incredible artists on this project.
<div>Director &amp
<div>Producer &amp
PR: Emily Owens
Art/Marketing: Hayes Thornton
<div>Cast: <span style=""background-color: initial
Designers:
Lights: Oona Curley
Set: Kimie Nishikawa
Sound: Kevin Novinsky
Costume: Spencer Olson

The Impact

This is an important play and very personal to me. It explores a fascinating historical character through an anachronistic lens, asking questions like: what are the standards of female beauty? How do we exercise control over other people? How do we acquiesce to that control from others? Working against the grain of a historical drama, this is a lively, sensual, and visceral piece of theater about female beauty standards. It was written for the present moment. 

  • Our goals for this project are to get as many people to see it and talk about these issues as possible, and your donation will help make the show the best it can possibly in order to spark these discussions.
  • My experience with self-producing has led to the creation of several successful shows in Los Angeles, Chicago and now New York and with your generosity I will be able to make this the best one yet.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate at this time, please SHARE this campaign, buy tickets to come see it, or share the ticket site with those who might be interested in coming to see the show!

  • Buy tickets to the show!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share on your social media page!

Thank you so much for your support! 

","LADY in New York this Fall

LADY is a new play about the lengths we go to for beauty and power. It's loosely based on Countess Bathory, who (if the rumors are true) killed over 600 young girls making her the worst serial killer in history. LADY and our team were chosen for the 2015 Araca Project and the play will have six performances at the American Theatre of Actors from October 28th-November 1st.  Hi, I'm Sofya, and I am the executive producer and playwright of this project. I have a history of self-producing, from high school to my theatre major studies at Loyola Marymount University. I recently graduated with my MFA in playwriting and screenwriting from Northwestern University, where I produced the quarterly MasterClash! reading series, and was commissioned by Steep Theatre to write a new play.  This is a fast and furious campaign in which we hope to raise more funds to put towards the investment from the Araca Project and a grant from Northwestern. This last piece of contribution will be instrumental in renting rehearsal space, getting important set pieces (i.e. a bathtub), paying our devoted artists who are offering up a month or their dedicated time, and lighting and sound packages to make this a polished, beautiful and thrilling piece of theatre.

Your donations will not only help us put on an incredibly effective, bold and beautiful show, but you will help ensure the future life of this production and help me make an impact on the theatrical world of New York City.

If you can't make it out to see the show, consider donating to help us make our dreams for this production and its future life in New York City. Be a part of something important and meaningful. The Haunting of Blaine Manor
England, 1953.

​Renowned American parapsychologist Doctor Roy Earle, famous for discrediting hauntings and exposing fake mediums, is invited to attend a seance in what is said to be the most haunted building in England, a building with a horrific history, Blaine Manor. Even the locals won’t set foot there, as all who walk within those grounds will be cursed.

But his arrival at the manor has awoken something, something horrific within the walls. As a raging storm closes off Blaine Manor from the outside world, Earle and the others find that what is waiting there is not nearly as horrific as what has entered with him…

My name is Joe O'Byrne, I'm a writer/director/actor from Manchester more known for a series of interconnected plays and films known as Tales from Paradise Heights.  The plays have had a successful life 'oop north', and reviewers have referred to me as the new Jimmy Mcgovern and the Salford Scorsese among many other things.
http://ilovemanchester.com/2017/09/07/meet-man-whos-called-scorsese-salford.aspx
For more on the existing body of work visit the Tales from Paradise Heights website at the link below.
http://www.talesfromparadiseheights.com/welcome.html

I like fresh challenges, and I've always wanted to do a haunted house story. Not just a ghost story though. I wanted it to be a period piece, something that would fit the world of M R James, Edgar Allan Poe or H P Lovecraft.  At the same time tipping the hat to the Hammer Horror Classics that I watched in my youth, classics that tapped into England’s rich cultural history of haunted castles, demons and witchcraft.    Blaine Manor has something of the Borley Rectory about it.  

In tandem with this I also wanted to create something that was a throwback to the Hollywood Golden Age, where glamour mixed with danger like bourbon poured over rocks, where you would see the likes of Claude Rains, Vincent Price, Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre, Boris Karloff, Bette Davis, Humphrey Bogart, Robert Mitchum, Lauren Bacall, Ida Lupino and Virginia Mayo (so many more, but I'd be here forever) strutting their stuff. I think they'd all feel at home in Blaine Manor.

Now, add an enormously talented cast and crew who each bring their own particular brand of skills, stir, bring to the boil and voila.  I can safely say that those initial goals have been achieved.  The play has done magnificently on its two opening runs in 2016, many people returning to see the play more than once.  But you don't have to take our word for it, below are just a selection of the fine reviews the show has thus far received.

Now we know we have something special here, a spine tingler with a feel of An Inspector Calls, The House on Haunted Hill and indeed a challenger to the magnificent The Woman in Black. There's a real buzz already starting around us returning in October for a short winter tour - finishing at the prestigious London Horror Festival at The Red Lion London .  The show will fly, we have no doubt about that.

But we want to look beyond the tour, we want to have runs in London where, hopefully and with strategic planning, the play will be spotted, taken on and launched into the West End. This in turn will act as the spearhead to launch the Tales from Paradise Heights series of plays in London, plays that each have had their own spectacular reviews, but when viewed as a body of work will be seen for what they have already been called - A Canterbury Tales for Today.

This is it, the one shot, the title shot - to launch The Haunting of Blaine Manor as one of the most original spine chillers to ever hit a stage, good enough and grand enough to challenge The Woman in Black herself, can you help us make our mark?  Anything you can spare, from a pound to a tenner to whatever you can, every penny will be put to taking The Haunting of Blaine Manor across those first few hurdles.  Join us.
Below is a link to the play's page on the website, here you will find galleries, videos and reviews and be able to keep up with all developments on the play.
http://www.talesfromparadiseheights.com/the-haunting-of-blaine-manor.html
<h3>What We Need &amp
We're looking for around £6,000, a starting point a fund that will see us through the Halloween tour (Salford, Oswestry, London) and lay the foundations for a longer run in London in the New Year.
Accommodation, 3 nights Oswestry, 2 nights London:   £2,600 (6 cast and 2 technicians)
Van Hire: £500 For 2 weeks transportation around 3 venues of a very large and handsome set.
Fuel:  £400 (Van and travel in 3 Cast and Crew Vehicles)
Posters/Flyers/Publicity:  £300
Cast &
column2: Crew:  20% of funds raised will be be used to pay the cast and crew of the production.

column1: Obviously the £6,000 is our goal and whatever funds are raised will go to this production and future performances of this production.  In return for your help we send you a huge thanks and perhaps we will see many of you out there,  there is also a list of perks opposite, all around the production and art.
Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, we're living in times of austerity and we totally recognise that.  But there may be other ways you can help,  you could help us make some noise around our campaign by:-
Sharing the campaign on social media or through your email.
Pointing the campaign in the direction of people that may be able to help.
Telling your friends about the play, sharing on social media.
Donations for the set
column2: items and paraphernalia that would not look out of place in a haunted manor.

column1: The sharing icons for the campaign are at the top of the page to the right of the introductory video.  Click on those to share across social media.
A big thank you for reading this and of course for any help at all that you can give us.

column1:
Show Summary:
Chicago's oldest cemetery is the backdrop for GRACELAND, the story of four lonely Chicagoans whose lives collide one August weekend while the Blue Angels airshow is in town. As fighter jets buzz the skies from dusk till dawn, estranged brother and sister Sam and Sara try to make sense of their father's recent suicide. Sara's one-night stand with Joe, an aging lothario, brings further trouble in the form of Joe's mercurial teenage son, Miles.

The story

My name is Sasha Ivanochko, and I am a choreographer, a pedagogue and the Artistic Director of a company I founded in 2005. Formerly known as blackandblue dance projects, our repertoire was built upon my personal movement aesthetic, and was richly influenced  by my own psychical expanse. The company was blessed to perform these works for audiences across Canada, in Japan, and the Caribbean. After 10 years of creating and touring, I began to think beyond my own movement to consider much more closely the bodies of others, specifically those of women and other minorities and how they are situated and constrained in the theatrical and public spheres. In 2015, I dug really deep into researching this topic at graduate school, and I have just recently emerged with a Master of Fine Arts degree, a re-envisioned company mandate, and two beautiful new solos for dancers Kristy Kennedy and Alana Elmer. 

Ivanochko et Cie is built upon feminist values of gender equality and sexual difference. Our body-driven, interdisciplinary practice questions disciplinary conventions and cultural norms, and creates space for alternative possibilities and narratives of the body to emerge. While the fight for equality has changed over the years, stereotypes remain. Women still fight subjugation and violence daily. Mirror Staging the Seeing Place and Modern Woman in Search of Soul are choreographies that aim to reconfigure cultural representations that are embedded in the female body, and revise how we see and understand it.

I developed and produced Mirror Staging on not even a shoe-string for my MFA final project. Because it was created within an academic setting, it was ineligible for government arts grants. Modern Woman has been developed through the company alongside my graduate studies. We are grateful to have received production funding from the Canada Council for the Arts, but we still have further stages of development to accomplish before the premiere. Modern Woman will be streamed live, and incorporates an innovative, interactive design by Jacob Niedzwiecki. Our final three-week rehearsal process will be focussed on developing this aspect of the show. In addition to the live-streaming, both pieces are accompanied by original music scores played live on-stage. The technical components of each work are huge. The mixing of media - sound, sight, light and interactive technology - requires 15 artists, designers and technicians to accomplish.

What We Need

The total cost of the production comes to $56,000. In addition to our one production grant, we will also receive a small performance fee from producer Citadel &
column2:
Compagnie, and we will apply for travel funds to bring our team (who are spread out across North America) to Toronto.

We still need $20,000 to complete our budget to mount this exceptional double bill. 

If you can make a donation to our project, it will go directly towards the fees of our collaborative team and the technical equipment required to bring our work to life. 

The Impact

The last time we produced a full-evening length work was in 2013. While I have been extremely active with my studies, teaching in universities and dance conservatories, and performing past rep across North America, the company has been largely dormant for the past few years. My studies have deeply influenced the way I think about my practice, and have altered the nature of the work itself. I am deeply concerned with the socio-political implications of choreographing others.

To be presented at The Citadel -a prominent venue in Toronto- is an important opportunity for the company at this time. It signals to the national milieu that the company is back in production mode, with a new profile, and beautifully crafted works that are ready to tour.

Risks and challenges

Dance is a visual art form that is expressed through the human body. There are a lot of humans working doggedly on these pieces with me. The company is blessed with a team of excellent, loyal collaborators, many of whom who have volunteered or have worked at bare minimum industry fee standards while I focussed on deepening my practice at graduate school (AKA, not making money). Falling below our $20,000 goal will make it impossible to mount this double bill. 

Here are the names of the humans working on this project:

Sasha Ivanochko, Artistic Director/Choreographer.   Jacob Niedzwiecki, Interactive Designer/Performer.   Kristy Kennedy, Performer.   Alana Elmer, Performer.   Karine Gauthier, Lighting Designer.   Vicky Mettler, Composer/Musician.   Raphaël Foisy-Couture, Composer. Matthew Ariaratnam, Composer/Musician.   Tanya White, Costume Designer.   Phil Strong, Head of Sound.   Simon Rossiter, Lighting Operator.   Dan Wild, Performance Coach.   And our yet to be named Stage Manager, Interactive Design Assistant, and Technical Director.

How you can help!!

Every penny generated will help us reach our goal. For instance, I have approximately 1500 friends on facebook. If each friend donated just $10, we’d reach 3/4 of our goal!

If you are able to make a large donation, please contact me directly. It is possible for us to give a tax receipt for one or two major donations.

If you can’t make a donation, please share this campaign with others who may, and help spread the word about our project. Every single contribution is of enormous value!

Thank you for your consideration! From the centre of my heart to yours, Sasha.

*All photos of Kristy Kennedy were taken by Tyler Pengelly. The video was filmed by Sophia Wolfe and edited by Ivanka Haney.

Who are we and what are we doing?
I am Maddy Moore and I am the Artistic Director of The Thelmas, and director of LADYKILLER by Madeline Gould.

The Thelmas is a female-led theatre company which comprises of myself and my co-director, playwright, Guleraana Mir who is co-producing Ladykiller. The Thelmas was set up to develop and promote early career female writers, and this year, not satisfied with having completed our first National tour, we are going to be making our Edinburgh Fringe Debut with a rollercoaster of a one woman show, Ladykiller by a brilliantly audacious and talent playwright, Madeline Gould.  The play stars the unbelievably watchable London-based, Northern Irish actor, Hannah McClean, who is also making her fringe debut.
A chambermaid, a hotel room and a dead woman. It’s not what it looks like, really, it’s not. It was self-defence… and anyway the woman was asking for it
The chambermaid considers herself to be a pretty normal person
column2: she reads books. She pretended to read the party manifestos at the General Election.  She’s even read The Psychopath Test and she’s pretty sure she’s not one so…

column1: Ladykiller is a blood-soaked morality tale about social responsibility, zero-hours contracts and tearing up the gender rule book on psychopathy
column2: a jet-black comedy for the age of the gig economy.  It charts one woman's journey through victimhood, from violent oppression to bloody revolution.

column1: It is  a comedy.
Why do we need you?
We are a pretty resilient bunch, but everyone needs someone right? So at this time, we need you to help us make Ladykiller the success it deserves to be.

Edinburgh Fringe is HUGE - this year there are over 3500 shows in town featuring 30,000+ performers. We are a small, but thriving 'young' theatre company with big ambitions. So far we have self-funded our productions on favours and our day-jobs, but more recently have been awarded grants from Arts Council England for Guleraana's recent play 'Coconut'.... twice! However, the Arts Council doesn't fund shows going to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and while we have some money made from touring to re-invest, we need to raise an additional £9k to ensure we have a successful, safe and sustainable run at the fringe and beyond.
However, it is more than that
column2: by showing your support for us and our work, you will also contributing to the good will, buzz and excitement not only around the show, but also around us as an up-and-coming, female-led company which is smashing more than a few stereotypes, drawing in new and diverse audiences, and helping to support women to bring fresh stories to the UK theatre scene. We are interested in building a solid base for the company, and for this to happen we want people who are passionate about supporting the artists of the future - that's you and us btw...

column1: Even a £1 or a share on your social media channels does this - nothing is too small and everything is hugely appreciated.
Your contribution will make a huge difference.

Our budget covers our production costs, like set and the construction of our 'victim'.... yes, a fake dead body basically. It will also go towards *really* sexy things like insurance, PRS and photocopying.
It covers travel and accommodation for the whole team.
In order to stand out from the crowd, our marketing budget is probably our biggest spend, but we feel that with our eye-catching image of Hannah, it is going to be really effective.
On top of this we want to be able to pay the team minimum Equity fringe rates - it's bloody hard work putting on a show so we believe that everyone should be paid as best we can.
Let us break it down for you a bit more:
<ul>
• £1 is 5 miles of petrol on our 402.5 mile drive to Edinburgh.
• £10 pays for 60 mins of street flyering (x 2 hours per day for 27 days... well you can do the maths right?)
• £30 will buy us an extra large bumper container of realistic looking and durable fake blood (plus a few packs of baby wipes to remove it from Hannah and the set after the show!)
• £60 will cover the cost of Hannah's costume and spares
• £100 hires us our extra lights to make Hannah look extra creepy!
• £150 buys us a ultra sexy, large outdoor advertising board
• £170 allows us to caption the show for the hearing impaired
• £250 would allow us to film the show to help us book future tours
• £300 covers the Fringe entry fee
• £600 covers our venue's marketing contra
• £1800 will cover our print advertising and digital marketing costs.
• £2000 will pay for our accommodation for the full month of the fringe.
The Impact

We want to become a commercially viable company, making theatre which entertains, but also encourages you to laugh your way into deeper conversation about the themes in the bar after the show.  Our work is best summed up by this quote from one reviewer:

column2: >‘An all-female cast and crew making theatre that people like - maybe that's the best kind of feminism.'- View from the Gods

column1: Ladykiller is a show which we believe is genuinely different - we genuinely have never seen a character quite like her on stage before. Our protagonist is not likeable. She is not someone you can root for. She says and does the things we fantasise about doing only in our very deepest, darkest moments.  At a recent preview showing an audience member reacted thus,
'I loved it. So dark it was like a beautiful black hole!'

Ladykiller demonstrates very clearly how rare it is that we see women's capacity for violence and evil portrayed in the media.  At a time when we as a society are examining our gender roles more so than any other, this show taps into this conversation in a most unexpected way.
We think this is an important conversation worth having.
Our presence at the fringe will achieve three really clear aims:
<ul>
• To showcase our work allowing potential programmers to see it and meet us, thus maximising our future earning potential.
• To allow us access to members of the industry we would never normally get to meet - this enables us to start to forge partnerships for both our production and participatory work.
• To expose our work and the company to a wider National and International audience.

We are thoroughly determined to make Edinburgh Fringe the next success on the ladder to us becoming a sustainable touring theatre company.  We have recent produced a very successful tour of Guleraana's play, 'Coconut', supported by In Good Company, the East Midlands flagship artist support programme. Last year we were a New Diorama Emerging company. Since 2016 we've been given time, advice, space, and opportunities by Derby Theatre, Oldham Coliseum, Park Theatre, Ovalhouse, The Space, New Diorama, Old Diorama, Canal Cafe Theatre, and RADA so we feel that even though this is our fringe debut, we are a pretty safe bet in terms of our theatrical pedigree:
<ul>

• Maddy (producer/director) was invited to be part of the Fringe Society's Emerging Producer Programme in 2017 which allowed her to forge a relationship with our venue for this year and learn the ropes of producing at the biggest fringe festival in the world. Maddy has had recent successes as a director at the helm of project like 'Coconut' by Guleraana Mir and multiple OFFIE and Broadway World award nominated, 'The Awakening' by Julian Garner.
• We have been chosen by The Pleasance to be part of their programme - The Pleasance is one of 'the big four' venues on the fringe and in our books, the very best!

• Maddie (writer) is a seasoned Edinburgh Fringe creative and has had recent critical acclaim with her immersive wartime drama, 'Think of England' at this year's Vault Festival and is Associate Writer for Anonymous is a Woman theatre company.

However, as a relatively new company while we have a good following in London and the surrounding area, within the wider industry we are not that well known... yet. This is something we want to change by going to the fringe. Both Maddy and Guleraana will be feet on the ground at as many industry events we can blag, bribe or burrow our way into - Maddy, having been Industry accredited last year now has the skinny on this and will be ready with her elevator pitch!

Likewise for developing our audience, this is a chance for us to share our work with a wider National and International audience base. We know our audience is likely to be young (20-35), digitally native and culturally curious, so we will be running a consistent witty and visually impactful social media campaign (see our trailer for example) through-out the fringe, as well as targeting our street flyering at the places these fringe-goers hang out.
Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that these are uncertain times and many, many of our friends are also artists raising funds for their own projects, so if you can't help by contributing there are lots of other things you can do to help:
<ul>
<li>Make some noise about our campaign and the show
column2: tweet it, share it, Instagram Hannah's lovely blood-splattered face.... Indiegogo have made these handy little share tools to make it dead easy.

column1: • You could commit to finding one person who might give something on your recommendation.
• You can also buy a ticket to the show, and come along and see it in Edinburgh.
• If you know any journalists, hook us up. Theatre programmer friends? E-introduce us!
• Recommend the show to a friend and show them our gory trailer!

We appreciate each and every effort you make to help us make Ladykiller smash the fringe! 

Thank you! :o)

Maddy, Guleraana, Maddie, Hannah, Jennifer and Baska.
