THE STORY
Love &
column2: Pride is about 6 individuals who identify at different points along the spectrums of gender, sex, and sexuality, and the conflicts that arise within themselves and their relationships due to those identities.  The story is set during a summer in San Francisco, and we watch these characters go through profound changes against the backdrop of iconic San Francisco events like Bay2Breakers, Folsom Street Fair, and of course, Pride.

column1: I started writing this story while I was in college majoring in theater, gender studies, and music.  to my dismay, I virtually never came across anything about queerness in the ways the ways that I or my friends experienced.  I found a deep lack of nuance, critical thinking, and representation...so I was inspired and determined to write songs that gave visibility to these identities, write a play that confronted these issues head on, and portray stories I have never seen on stage before.
WHAT WE NEED
We are doing this crowdfunding campaign because have Love &
column2: Pride booked at the SF LGBT Center for a 4 week run beginning this October.  This is so exciting because they are one of the leading organizations that fight for the community the play is about.

column1: The amount we're raising is to cover the cost of renting the venue space, which is due before the show opens on October 18, 2018: Performances $480 per night x 4 nights =  $1920 + Technical Rehearsal $555 per night x 1 night = $555 = TOTAL NEEDED: $2475

column3: '>We are offering special reserved seating as Our Love perk for $25.  You can purchase this ticket for your self, or donate your ticket to a student.  We are currently working with high schools and colleges who are interested in bringing a group of their students to see the show.

column1: Inequality, prejudice, and violence against queer, trans and non-binary folks are still prevalent all over the world.  While this play centers on the topics of gender and sexuality, it is ultimately about the universal themes of finding your true self and learning to love others for who they truly are.  My hopes for this project that it fosters dialogue about complex and controversial topics, and creates awareness for marginalized communities - so that we can all relate to the struggles and joys of love, and be proud of that love, no matter how we identify

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please Like and Follow all of our pages and help Spread the Word about this show by sharing this campaign and all of our social media with your networks!

https://igg.me/at/loveandpridethemusicalSFLGBT

http://loveandpridethemusical.com

https://www.instagram.com/loveandpridethemusical/

https://www.facebook.com/loveandpridethemusical/

https://twitter.com/loveandpridesf

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbjht-uw6gznWkjWNhkKoSg

Any amount and every share truly helps and will be very much appreciated! 

This is more than a musical, it's a movement...join our Pride!

","THE STORY

Love & Pride is about 6 individuals who identify at different points along the spectrums of gender, sex, and sexuality, and the conflicts that arise within themselves and their relationships due to those identities.  The story is set during a summer in San Francisco, and we watch these characters go through profound changes against the backdrop of iconic San Francisco events like Bay2Breakers, Folsom Street Fair, and of course, Pride.

I started writing this story while I was in college majoring in theater, gender studies, and music.  to my dismay, I virtually never came across anything about queerness in the ways the ways that I or my friends experienced.  I found a deep lack of nuance, critical thinking, and representation...so I was inspired and determined to write songs that gave visibility to these identities, write a play that confronted these issues head on, and portray stories I have never seen on stage before.
WHAT WE NEED

We are doing this crowdfunding campaign because have Love & Pride booked at the SF LGBT Center for a 4 week run beginning this October.  This is so exciting because they are one of the leading organizations that fight for the community the play is about.

The amount we're raising is to cover the cost of renting the venue space, which is due before the show opens on October 18, 2018: Performances $480 per night x 4 nights =  $1920 + Technical Rehearsal $555 per night x 1 night = $555 = TOTAL NEEDED: $2475
WHAT YOU GET

We are offering special reserved seating as Our Love perk for $25.  You can purchase this ticket for your self, or donate your ticket to a student.  We are currently working with high schools and colleges who are interested in bringing a group of their students to see the show.
WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT

Inequality, prejudice, and violence against queer, trans and non-binary folks are still prevalent all over the world.  While this play centers on the topics of gender and sexuality, it is ultimately about the universal themes of finding your true self and learning to love others for who they truly are.  My hopes for this project that it fosters dialogue about complex and controversial topics, and creates awareness for marginalized communities - so that we can all relate to the struggles and joys of love, and be proud of that love, no matter how we identify

Theater Costs Money

Yeah, yeah, yeah... we've heard about the Poor Theater. We're not talking about that. We're talking about the Paying Theater. Padua Playwrights has been churning out avant-garde masterpieces for 40+ years. Ever heard of Sam Shepard? Murray Mednick? Marie Irene-Fornes? Well guess what? Writing is great, but we want to produce some large-scale, touring productions and pay actors a living wage. We want a theater company in an actual building where our actors, designers, writers, and directors are on staff and get health benefits. We also want a pony. We will care for the pony and treat the pony as if it were a member of the family. We shall call it ""Pony"" and it shall live a fine, fine life.
One big bonus is that Padua Playwrights is a bona fide 501c3 non-profit corporation so all of your donations are fully tax deductible!
Short Term:

We're raising funds for Jack Benny: A Menage En Train, showing at the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June. Over 7 months in creation, this collaboratively written, communally performed, kinetic cabaret directed by Juli Crockett is specially formulated to melt your mind and confuse your senses.
Longer Term:

We're launching PaduaLab! The soon-expanding producing arm of Padua Playwrights, helmed by Producing Director Juli Crockett. Focused on bringing writers, directors, performers, designers, and producers together to make groundbreaking avant-garde theater in Los Angeles, PaduaLab is specially formulated to melt your mind and confuse your senses.
Who ARE We?
For the purposes of Jack Benny @ Fringe, we are:
Juli Crockett, Gray Palmer, &
Juli Crockett (Director)
Gabrieal Griego &
Shaughn Buchholz (Performer)
Gray Palmer (Performer)
Jenny Greer (Performer)
Juli Crockett (Performer)
Brian Tichnell (Performer)
John Zalewski (Sound Designer)
Bri Pattillo (Lighting Designer)
YOU KNOW US!
We Need Money

We'll take what we can get. For this campaign we've set our goal for $8k, which will cover our Jack Benny run, take care of all our collaborators and expenses, and put a little in the hopper for the impending launch of PADUALAB RADIO, the Padua Playwrights podcast bringing you the finest in avant-garde sonic theater art and guided writing meditations.
Look at those Perks!

They're great. They're weird. Hopefully there is something for you. If not, drop us a line and we'll make some new ones. We have the power, the will, and the technical know-how. You should read them, though. They are pretty delightful. I've tried to write enough here to keep the Perks balance with the Story. So, read on!
And one more time: Padua Playwrights is a bona fide 501c3 non-profit corporation so all of your donations are fully tax deductible!
What the Hell is Jack Benny?

For the purposes of this fundraising mission, Jack Benny: A Menage En Train is a show at the Hollywood Fringe Festival. The ridiculous summit of the mountain of theatrical tomfoolery we have been engaged with. Why is Jack Benny? Who knows! But we can tell you HOW the Jack Benny became an IS.

The tools: script, stopwatch, tape-recorder, archive, time, exact witness. Using the script of a scene from The Jack Benny Show as a prompt, several lines were read from the script. Then writers wrote privately for ten minutes. We turned on the tape-recorder, and each read in turn from our material, not all-through, but passing to the left when the spirit moved, as an answer or an interruption, till all the material of the ten-minute period was exhausted. We repeated.
Narratives and phantom narratives arrived, congealed, and vanished through this procedure: a surprising body or spirit seemed to be forming.
We repeated this process. A transcript was prepared from the tapes, a block text without attribution of voices. That transcript, without changes, is the text of the original play.

Next, the performative phase. Material was read by different assortments of actors. As Director, I dictated attribution of lines, by a somewhat mysterious process of selection, to four characters. As a guiding principle, the things said need not have a direct relation to the action of the characters (Poetry). Performatively, these were four spies traveling together, sometimes speaking in code, and stage is devised action accordingly.

The play is the centerpiece of an evolving variety show. The aim is a internationally-touring, self-sufficient, ever-evolving, deeply-inhabited self-contained production that is executed by the performers, whom after long exposure, repetition, and familiarity, deliver the text with the same ease and concentration as the brushing of teeth. Ritual art hygiene for a cluttered world.

Donate and ask nicely, perhaps we will send you the original text of Jack Benny (long form) and the script version so you can see for yourself, not a word was changed to create this mysterious masterpiece!
p.s. If you're still reading, here's some more stuff to read about the history of Padua Playwrights.
History of Padua Playwrights

In 1978, Murray Mednick and five other playwrights, including Sam Shepard and Maria Irene Fornes, converged on the old Padua Hills estate in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, just east of Los Angeles. The playwrights, as well as playwriting students and actors, were given free reign to re-investigate their creativity, developing writing exercises for the morning, rehearsing in the afternoon, and presenting the results in the evening.

Under Mednick’s artistic direction through 1995, the Festival and Workshop became a model that, staged annually, had a lasting impact on American theater. In 2001, under the artistic direction of playwright and director Guy Zimmerman, Padua began offering regular seasons of new work to critical acclaim. In its first ten seasons the company staged 28 productions, including three in New York City and three abroad, and garnered a host of LA Weekly, Garland, and Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle awards and an American Theatre Critics Association citation. Since 2003, the company has published six play anthologies, distributed nationally by Theatre Communications Group, including two new play anthologies slated for the Winter of 2012.

Among the many prominent playwrights to emerge from or be nurtured by Padua are: David Henry Hwang, John Steppling, John O’Keefe, Kelly Stuart, Jon Robin Baitz, Marlane Meyer, Guy Zimmerman, Wesley Walker, Julie Hebert, Susan Champagne, Sharon Yablon, Susan Mosakowski, and Joseph Goodrich, to name a few.
It Ain't Easy

We're a group of amazing people with lots of experience. We make the darkness visible. We just haven't yet succeeded in the alchemy of turning balsamic vinegar into gold. So, we're fundraising. It's not easy, and it's not fun, but we've tried to make it as fun and easy as possible by putting it on this platform where you can donate with ease and get fun perks. If you're all business, you can also check out this Sponsorship page on the Padua site.
No Money? Be a Honey!

You're broke? No worries. You can still help. If you've got a computer and a social media account, you can help us post and share this campaign and spread the good word. You can post info about our Jack Benny show at Fringe. If you've seen the show (and loved it, ideally) you can write us a review.
And of course, we always can use volunteers at Padua to help with our shows, promotions, outreach, productions, workshops, and more.
I Can't Go On. I Must Go On.

If there is something said or unsaid that would have made the difference of donating or not donating, please add, edit, or mute in your mind and go ahead and hit the donate button. We are the last line of defense against a world that want to take a crap inside of your brain and soul every day, in every way. Help us fight the good fight.
Absurdly yours,
PaduaLab
Boom!
","Theater Costs Money

Yeah, yeah, yeah... we've heard about the Poor Theater. We're not talking about that. We're talking about the Paying Theater. Padua Playwrights has been churning out avant-garde masterpieces for 40+ years. Ever heard of Sam Shepard? Murray Mednick? Marie Irene-Fornes? Well guess what? Writing is great, but we want to produce some large-scale, touring productions and pay actors a living wage. We want a theater company in an actual building where our actors, designers, writers, and directors are on staff and get health benefits. We also want a pony. We will care for the pony and treat the pony as if it were a member of the family. We shall call it ""Pony"" and it shall live a fine, fine life.
One big bonus is that Padua Playwrights is a bona fide 501c3 non-profit corporation so all of your donations are fully tax deductible!
Short Term:

We're raising funds for Jack Benny: A Menage En Train, showing at the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June. Over 7 months in creation, this collaboratively written, communally performed, kinetic cabaret directed by Juli Crockett is specially formulated to melt your mind and confuse your senses.
Longer Term:

We're launching PaduaLab! The soon-expanding producing arm of Padua Playwrights, helmed by Producing Director Juli Crockett. Focused on bringing writers, directors, performers, designers, and producers together to make groundbreaking avant-garde theater in Los Angeles, PaduaLab is specially formulated to melt your mind and confuse your senses.
Who ARE We?
For the purposes of Jack Benny @ Fringe, we are:
Juli Crockett, Gray Palmer, & Guy Zimmerman (Writers)
Juli Crockett (Director)
Gabrieal Griego & Guy Zimmerman (Producers)
Shaughn Buchholz (Performer)
Gray Palmer (Performer)
Jenny Greer (Performer)
Juli Crockett (Performer)
Brian Tichnell (Performer)
John Zalewski (Sound Designer)
Bri Pattillo (Lighting Designer)
YOU KNOW US!
We Need Money

We'll take what we can get. For this campaign we've set our goal for $8k, which will cover our Jack Benny run, take care of all our collaborators and expenses, and put a little in the hopper for the impending launch of PADUALAB RADIO, the Padua Playwrights podcast bringing you the finest in avant-garde sonic theater art and guided writing meditations.
Look at those Perks!

They're great. They're weird. Hopefully there is something for you. If not, drop us a line and we'll make some new ones. We have the power, the will, and the technical know-how. You should read them, though. They are pretty delightful. I've tried to write enough here to keep the Perks balance with the Story. So, read on!
And one more time: Padua Playwrights is a bona fide 501c3 non-profit corporation so all of your donations are fully tax deductible!
What the Hell is Jack Benny?

For the purposes of this fundraising mission, Jack Benny: A Menage En Train is a show at the Hollywood Fringe Festival. The ridiculous summit of the mountain of theatrical tomfoolery we have been engaged with. Why is Jack Benny? Who knows! But we can tell you HOW the Jack Benny became an IS.

The tools: script, stopwatch, tape-recorder, archive, time, exact witness. Using the script of a scene from The Jack Benny Show as a prompt, several lines were read from the script. Then writers wrote privately for ten minutes. We turned on the tape-recorder, and each read in turn from our material, not all-through, but passing to the left when the spirit moved, as an answer or an interruption, till all the material of the ten-minute period was exhausted. We repeated.
Narratives and phantom narratives arrived, congealed, and vanished through this procedure: a surprising body or spirit seemed to be forming.
We repeated this process. A transcript was prepared from the tapes, a block text without attribution of voices. That transcript, without changes, is the text of the original play.

Next, the performative phase. Material was read by different assortments of actors. As Director, I dictated attribution of lines, by a somewhat mysterious process of selection, to four characters. As a guiding principle, the things said need not have a direct relation to the action of the characters (Poetry). Performatively, these were four spies traveling together, sometimes speaking in code, and stage is devised action accordingly.

The play is the centerpiece of an evolving variety show. The aim is a internationally-touring, self-sufficient, ever-evolving, deeply-inhabited self-contained production that is executed by the performers, whom after long exposure, repetition, and familiarity, deliver the text with the same ease and concentration as the brushing of teeth. Ritual art hygiene for a cluttered world.

Donate and ask nicely, perhaps we will send you the original text of Jack Benny (long form) and the script version so you can see for yourself, not a word was changed to create this mysterious masterpiece!
p.s. If you're still reading, here's some more stuff to read about the history of Padua Playwrights.
History of Padua Playwrights

In 1978, Murray Mednick and five other playwrights, including Sam Shepard and Maria Irene Fornes, converged on the old Padua Hills estate in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, just east of Los Angeles. The playwrights, as well as playwriting students and actors, were given free reign to re-investigate their creativity, developing writing exercises for the morning, rehearsing in the afternoon, and presenting the results in the evening.

Under Mednick’s artistic direction through 1995, the Festival and Workshop became a model that, staged annually, had a lasting impact on American theater. In 2001, under the artistic direction of playwright and director Guy Zimmerman, Padua began offering regular seasons of new work to critical acclaim. In its first ten seasons the company staged 28 productions, including three in New York City and three abroad, and garnered a host of LA Weekly, Garland, and Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle awards and an American Theatre Critics Association citation. Since 2003, the company has published six play anthologies, distributed nationally by Theatre Communications Group, including two new play anthologies slated for the Winter of 2012.

Among the many prominent playwrights to emerge from or be nurtured by Padua are: David Henry Hwang, John Steppling, John O’Keefe, Kelly Stuart, Jon Robin Baitz, Marlane Meyer, Guy Zimmerman, Wesley Walker, Julie Hebert, Susan Champagne, Sharon Yablon, Susan Mosakowski, and Joseph Goodrich, to name a few.
It Ain't Easy

We're a group of amazing people with lots of experience. We make the darkness visible. We just haven't yet succeeded in the alchemy of turning balsamic vinegar into gold. So, we're fundraising. It's not easy, and it's not fun, but we've tried to make it as fun and easy as possible by putting it on this platform where you can donate with ease and get fun perks. If you're all business, you can also check out this Sponsorship page on the Padua site.
No Money? Be a Honey!

You're broke? No worries. You can still help. If you've got a computer and a social media account, you can help us post and share this campaign and spread the good word. You can post info about our Jack Benny show at Fringe. If you've seen the show (and loved it, ideally) you can write us a review.
And of course, we always can use volunteers at Padua to help with our shows, promotions, outreach, productions, workshops, and more.
I Can't Go On. I Must Go On.

If there is something said or unsaid that would have made the difference of donating or not donating, please add, edit, or mute in your mind and go ahead and hit the donate button. We are the last line of defense against a world that want to take a crap inside of your brain and soul every day, in every way. Help us fight the good fight.
Absurdly yours,
PaduaLab

Help Us Bring Our Show to the Ashtar Youth Theatre Festival
This is a rare opportunity to sponsor a cross-cultural collaboration between American and Palestinian youth theatre artists.

We are the debut cohort of the Co-Op Theatre East youth ensemble. We have been invited to attend the 2018 Ashtar Youth Theatre Festival in the West Bank where we will spend 10 days performing and participating in theatre education workshops with artists from across the world.

We are creating an original ensemble devised theatre piece on the theme of the festival, ascension. Our show, called The Waiting Room is being created by five performers in New York City. Utilizing movement, music and text, the show looks at questions of home, identity, systems of power and internal oppression.
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are raising $10,000 to help subsidize our plane fare and provide stipends to our hard-working young artists while going abroad this summer. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for many of us who are interested in utilizing theatre and the arts to build bridges between cultures and as a tool for political and social activism.

The money raised by our Indiegogo Campaign will go directly to support our plane fare and provide small living stipends to our artists who are taking time off of work to attend the festival. The money will also go to help purchase costumes, props and space for our New York City performance of this show in the fall. By funding this project, we will be able to focus on our work as opposed to working several jobs to pay off the tickets.
The Impact

This is a rare opportunity to visit the West Bank and meet international artists and hear from artists that rarely get a voice on the American stage. We are excited to speak with Palestinian artists. We're also excited to bring the experience back to the US and share with audiences here the work that's being done by theatre-makers in Palestine and across the globe.
Other Ways You Can Help
Join us on June 24th for our fundraising brunch!
Follow Us:
@cooptheatreeast
#CoopTheatreEast
#COTEYouthEnsemble
#AshtarTheatreFestival
#COTEinAshtar
Watch Videos of Previous Years from the Ashtar Youth Theatre Festival

Here's how it started:

The day after I saw that production of Measure for Measure, I was listless and depressed. I thought of the Isabella/Angelo scene and I cried. I texted my friend who I’d seen the show with and it turned out she had also been depressed all day and thought the show had triggered it.

It was an excellent production. It was moving and aesthetically exciting and it made me never want to see Measure for Measure again. As we walked away from the theatre, my friend and I – both of us lifelong Shakespeare nerds and passionate Shakespeare educators – talked about all the plays we may have had our fill of. This same company’s Othello had similarly given me a definitive production and made me never want to see Othello again. My friend had had her fill of A Midsummer Night’s Dream after watching all of the women get humiliated so much while teaching it.

I was almost ready to just call it a day with Shakespeare. Like – really. I’m a playwright. To hell with it. I can write my own damn plays. I already do, in fact. I don’t need his anymore. You’ve loved something enough, you can let it go, right?

Then, at dinner, while I tried not to cry into my bi bim bap, my partner wondered if I’d feel similarly about Measure for Measure if instead of just silently accepting the Duke’s proposal, Isabella kicked him in the balls. I had to confess that that would have helped. And further suggestions of a bloody revolution at the end also cheered me right up. “As Isabella feeds The Duke into the wood chipper, a spray of blood covers the entire stage. End of play.” Wouldn’t need to change a single line of Shakespeare’s language and I would feel so much differently about this play.

And so – by the end of the night, I was scheming about how to do an experimental workshop to explore these ideas. I went from never wanting to see Measure for Measure again to wanting to direct it -  in the space of a day.
Over the last year the state of the world has been such that I haven’t had the will to make any theatre. But I was suddenly energized to seize hold of this play and shake it til it cries for mercy.
I had ten free hours of rehearsal space and a nimble adaptable theatre company. So, with no prep, no preamble and no waiting, I dove right in. It’s instant feminist theatre.
So – if the space is free, why do we need money?
The artists who have signed on to explore this play need to be paid. This is a cast of all women and statistically women’s work is underpaid or unpaid. Please help me make this project different.

If we were able to pay every woman just NY’s current minimum wage of $13 per hour, for the ten hours we’ll be in their presence, that’s $130 per actor. However, there is a lot of work happening when we're not seeing them as well. Let’s call it $200 per actor for just the bare minimum. This doesn’t include the cost that a lot of our actors are incurring due to the location of our “free” rehearsal space. In Soraya Chemaly’s book, Rage Becomes Her, she discusses the Safety Tax – which is a premium that women often pay to stay safe in a misogynistic world. Our actors are incurring a safety tax during this process. A highly conservative estimate of that tax – that is, taking a car service due to the fact that the area is not well trafficked or well lit is a further $75 per actor.

For the ten people we have involved already, $275 per person brings us to $2750. But – in the course of this process, it has become clear that we need a chorus of additional performers which we’ll bring in for subsequent rehearsal. So assuming we’ll have them for the remainder of our time and that they too will be in a position of paying the safety tax, we’ll need an additional $1750 – bringing our total to $4500 – just to pay everyone a minimum wage and safety tax.
And believe me, I want so much to be able to pay them so much more than minimum wage. I imagine you might, as well.
Your donation is a vote for a more economically just feminist world.

It’s also a vote for a more process oriented world. Like our previous project (The Door Was Open) this is an exploration, Research and Development, a creative process and not a product. If you value such things, please consider making a donation.

Will we raise the funds we need to pay these ladies sufficiently? I don’t know. Historically, Indie Theatre is underfunded,  women’s work is radically underfunded and explicitly feminist work even less so. Will things remain as they are or be transformed? It’s up to you.

What is this project and why should I help fund it?
Bow &
column2: Arrow is a circus theater collective founded by four badass women: Marie &amp
column3: Genie Cartier, Bethlayne Hansen and Madi Worthington. By combining our diverse backgrounds in circus, theater, production and design, we are taking on the patriarchy by creating our own original independent circus theatre productions. Our recent productions have been yearly installments of Saturnalia: A Raunchy Circus Christmas, a fun, sexy circus show inspired by the Pagan origins of Christmas.

column1: The idea for “Dark Side of the Circus” was born many years ago when teenage circus performer Genie Cartier listened to Pink Floyd’s “Dark Side of the Moon” for the first time and thought “this should be a circus show.” The time for this idea has arrived. Not only is female leadership more needed than ever, a thoroughly entertaining and well-produced independent show is just what the doctor ordered in these dark times.

You should fund this show because artists deserve to be paid for their hard work. Because hard-working artists deserve to work in good conditions, wear fabulous costumes, and perform in a theater that can accommodate their needs. Because artists provide an invaluable service to our community and deserve to be recognized and compensated for it! Can I get an amen?
<h2>What We Need &amp
So here’s the deal:

We need $10,000 to give this show the treatment it deserves. To give you an idea of the costs, the theater rental alone for two weekends is $6000. The rest goes to production costs, publicity, and most importantly paying the cast &
We have some great perks, so take a look before you decide on an amount. Any donation over $100 includes one or more tickets to the show!

If we do not reach $10k, the funds we do raise will go towards the theater rental. That means everything else has to be borrowed against future ticket sales. It is very difficult to do this and pay artists fairly, so please help us reach our goal!
Impact
We at Bow &
column2: Arrow are intimately knowledgeable about the struggles of being a performer. Too often, we are forced to choose between meaningful, creative projects and projects that will pay. We want to change that norm. By contributing to this campaign, you are not only supporting one production, you are helping us shift the view of artists to a valuable demographic that deserves to be paid for their hard work like any other profession.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help

Want to contribute beyond your donation? Don’t have the funds, but still want to support us? Indiegogo makes it really easy to share the campaign across all platforms, so please help us get the word out!
","What is this project and why should I help fund it?

Bow & Arrow is a circus theater collective founded by four badass women: Marie & Genie Cartier, Bethlayne Hansen and Madi Worthington. By combining our diverse backgrounds in circus, theater, production and design, we are taking on the patriarchy by creating our own original independent circus theatre productions. Our recent productions have been yearly installments of Saturnalia: A Raunchy Circus Christmas, a fun, sexy circus show inspired by the Pagan origins of Christmas.

The idea for “Dark Side of the Circus” was born many years ago when teenage circus performer Genie Cartier listened to Pink Floyd’s “Dark Side of the Moon” for the first time and thought “this should be a circus show.” The time for this idea has arrived. Not only is female leadership more needed than ever, a thoroughly entertaining and well-produced independent show is just what the doctor ordered in these dark times.

You should fund this show because artists deserve to be paid for their hard work. Because hard-working artists deserve to work in good conditions, wear fabulous costumes, and perform in a theater that can accommodate their needs. Because artists provide an invaluable service to our community and deserve to be recognized and compensated for it! Can I get an amen?
What We Need & What You Get
So here’s the deal:

We need $10,000 to give this show the treatment it deserves. To give you an idea of the costs, the theater rental alone for two weekends is $6000. The rest goes to production costs, publicity, and most importantly paying the cast & crew!
We have some great perks, so take a look before you decide on an amount. Any donation over $100 includes one or more tickets to the show!

If we do not reach $10k, the funds we do raise will go towards the theater rental. That means everything else has to be borrowed against future ticket sales. It is very difficult to do this and pay artists fairly, so please help us reach our goal!
Impact

We at Bow & Arrow are intimately knowledgeable about the struggles of being a performer. Too often, we are forced to choose between meaningful, creative projects and projects that will pay. We want to change that norm. By contributing to this campaign, you are not only supporting one production, you are helping us shift the view of artists to a valuable demographic that deserves to be paid for their hard work like any other profession.

Hello all, and thank you for stopping by our page!

The senior cohort in the Acting program at Utah State University is raising money to attend The Mountain West Actor Showcase on March 11, 2019. This showcase will be our launching point into the professional world. Every year casting directors, agents, managers, and other industry professionals are invited to our showcase.

Through this showcase, Utah State Alumni have made connections around the United States. Many have found work in regional theatres across the country. Some are living in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago pursuing their dreams on stage and in film. Multiple students have booked agents and managers through this showcase which help guarantee them future work. This is the fifth year students from Utah State will be traveling to New York, and each year the success of the showcase has grown exponentially.

The expected total cost for this trip is around $20,000 for eight students. We are in the process of raising money by selling concessions at USU theater shows and performing in cabarets. We have also applied for several sources of university funding.

With the holiday season in full bloom, we wanted to give our friends and family an easy way to donate to our project. Any donations will go toward headshots, printing and distribution costs, travel to and from New York City, hotel rooms, and the rental of the theatre, accompanist, and piano for our performances.

If we are lucky enough to raise money beyond the essentials, any extra fundraising will go toward the further artistic education of the actors. Some students have never been to New York and would like to take this opportunity to indulge in the history of the city. Others are planning to attend advanced classes to get a taste of what will be available after graduation. Most would like to see at least one Broadway show while they are in such a brilliant theatre hub.

Thank you in advance for any donation. No amount is too small. If you are unable to contribute in this way, please share the link to our campaign. You can also support us by purchasing concessions at any Utah State Theatre production, or by attending the Last Chance Cabaret in early February.
Thank you again!
The Seniors
Anna Bodily, Eliza Shoell, Rachael Hodge, Mitch Shira, Dane Braddy, Noah Gentry, Travis Charron, and Tyler Campbell

Hi!  I'm Candice Oden, major star of stage, screen, and television.  Why have you not heard of me?  ... Well, maybe I'm not a major star -- that was misleading.  I am a singer/actor, though, who has been performing professionally for 27 years in all realms of the entertainment industry.  With the exception of mime.

I have created a musical evening of fun and drama that I have been working on off and on for a couple of years.  It's a free workshop production of my solo show that's very important to me -- it's important for me to tell my story so that people can get a glimpse of what it's like dealing with mental illness.  It's an area that I'm very passionate about, and it's time I did something about it, in a way that only I can.  And your contributions can make this dream I've had a reality.  If I open the eyes of even one person to the truth about bipolar disorder, I will have done my job.  And you can help make that happen!

I need to raise $2,000 to get this thing up and running.  That will help cover the costs of my musical director, my director, props, a sparse set, and sound equipment.  The Seeing Place is generously providing the space and stage manager, so those are covered.  Woohoo!  Naturally, as any good IndieGoGo campaign does, I have perks!  These very high class and expensive perks range from a shout out and stick figure drawings, all the way to an evening with Candice Oden at Taco Bell.  And don't worry, if these perks aren't exciting enough and I don't reach my goal, the funds are still going to this project.  Whether you can donate $1 or $2,000, your contribution means the world to me.  This show is so important to me.  And anything helps.
If you are also a starving artist and $1 is too much (I get it), spreading the word about the show and this campaign will have a huge impact.
Oh!  And did I mention -- this show is going to be free to the public!  That's one reason why this campaign is so important -- because I'll be making no money from the box office to cover costs.
The show is performing Wednesday, January 16th at 3pm and Saturday, January 19th at 5pm.
Come and enjoy the show!

The Saskatoon International Burlesque Festival will celebrate its first year at the Broadway Theatre in Saskatoon SK October 3-6 2019. The SIBF aims to produce the first ever, top quality, weekend-long professional Burlesque Festival in SK. The festival will include but not be limited to 2 full-scale performance showcases and a day of professional development workshops. We are pleased to co-produce the festival with The Broadway Theatre.

The SIBF’s goal is to include a wide variety of talented performers including people of colour, first nation people, people of all genders and variations, performers of a variety of ages, sizes, backgrounds, beliefs and sexual orientations. We will provide a safe space for artistic expression, performance and training opportunities.
<h2 style=""text-align: center
<h2 style=""text-align: center

While some performers “burst” onto the burlesque scene, Ava Lure’s ascent has resembled more of a high-viscosity ooze of angst and ardour. Performing burlesque since 2010, Ava has graced the stages of Wasabassco Burlesque NYC, the Vancouver International Burlesque Festival, Toronto Burlesque Festival, Edmonton Burlesque Festival, Texas Burlesque Festival, Minneapolis Burlesque Festival, and with Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society, the Burlesque Hall of Fame Weekender. Ava is currently a member of Pandora &
column2: The Locksmiths, an instructor with Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society, and the Creative Director and Founder of The Crystalline Cabaret.

column1: With a strong commitment to incorporating artistic education into her creative practice, Ava has a Diploma in Theatre as well as Alumni Award for Community Service from Douglas College, an Advanced Certiﬁcate in Arts &
column2: Entertainment Management and Bachelor of Performing Arts from Capilano University, and has studied Viewpoints Movement Improvisation from the Banff Centre for the Arts. Ava served on the board of the Vancouver International Burlesque festival for three years and was President in 2015. As a part of East Vancouver’s larger artistic community, Ava often collaborates with photographers, video and theatre artists, dancers, and designers on various projects outside of burlesque. Blending theatricality with timeless grace every time she hits the stage, her intoxicating movements lure you into her dream world.

column1: <h2 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Our co-feature is the lovely and flexible

column1: <h2 style=""text-align: center

Based out of Chicago, Dahlia Fatale is a travelling contortionist,  burlesque performer and instructor. Dahlia's performances combine the smoothness of classical dance training with the bizarre and superhuman styling of contortion. She has been featured at prestigious events across the US and Canada and loves bringing her unique art form to new and different audiences. As an artist, Dahlia loves to create characters which play with the boundaries (both physical and emotional) of burlesque and perception versus reality of humans. Regardless of the act she puts on that night, she's guaranteed to always bend your mind with her body!
The festival will also present 28 other performers from around the globe! You can keep your eye on our website at https://saskatooninternationalburlesquefestival.com/ for line up announcements.
<h2 style=""text-align: center

As you can imagine there is an awful lot that goes into producing a multi-day large scale event like this, especially for the first time! The Burlesque Festival and the Broadway Theatre are working hard to raise enough funds to cover the travel, accommodation and performance costs for our Headliner and Co-feature, theatre rentals and technician wages as well as our advertising costs. We also will guarantee each of our other 28 performers a performance fee, aid with finding billeting for out of town artists and provide affordable workshop/training opportunities with our stars.

We are a small independent group of burlesque fans partnering with a local not for profit to take the risk to produce the festival this season. Our production budget is just over $18,000 and through both our ticket sales and our fundraising initiatives like this one we hope that the festival is successful enough to ensure the future of the event!
Every little bit donated to this campaign will help to bring the Glitterati to Saskatoon! This festival will also act as a fundraising inititative for the Broadway Theatre Charitable Org.
Other ways to show us your sparkly love!

If you are unable to make a financial donation at this time but would like to help out there are a number of ways to get involved! You can find more information on how to support the festival here https://saskatooninternationalburlesquefestival.com/index.php/support/
Help us get this party started!​ Share this online campaign and help us to spread the word about this fabulous new festival!

The festival will include but not be limited to 2 full-scale performance showcases and a day of professional development workshops. We are pleased to co-produce the festival with The Broadway Theatre.

Announcing our festival headliner
Canadian Superstar Ava Lure

While some performers “burst” onto the burlesque scene, Ava Lure’s ascent has resembled more of a high-viscosity ooze of angst and ardour. Performing burlesque since 2010, Ava has graced the stages of Wasabassco Burlesque NYC, the Vancouver International Burlesque Festival, Toronto Burlesque Festival, Edmonton Burlesque Festival, Texas Burlesque Festival, Minneapolis Burlesque Festival, and with Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society, the Burlesque Hall of Fame Weekender. Ava is currently a member of Pandora & The Locksmiths, an instructor with Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society, and the Creative Director and Founder of The Crystalline Cabaret.

With a strong commitment to incorporating artistic education into her creative practice, Ava has a Diploma in Theatre as well as Alumni Award for Community Service from Douglas College, an Advanced Certiﬁcate in Arts & Entertainment Management and Bachelor of Performing Arts from Capilano University, and has studied Viewpoints Movement Improvisation from the Banff Centre for the Arts. Ava served on the board of the Vancouver International Burlesque festival for three years and was President in 2015. As a part of East Vancouver’s larger artistic community, Ava often collaborates with photographers, video and theatre artists, dancers, and designers on various projects outside of burlesque. Blending theatricality with timeless grace every time she hits the stage, her intoxicating movements lure you into her dream world.
Our co-feature is the lovely and flexible

She has been featured at prestigious events across the US and Canada and loves bringing her unique art form to new and different audiences. As an artist, Dahlia loves to create characters which play with the boundaries (both physical and emotional) of burlesque and perception versus reality of humans. The Burlesque Festival and the Broadway Theatre are working hard to raise enough funds to cover the travel, accommodation and performance costs for our Headliner and Co-feature, theatre rentals and technician wages as well as our advertising costs. We also will guarantee each of our other 28 performers a performance fee, aid with finding billeting for out of town artists and provide affordable workshop/training opportunities with our stars.

We are a small independent group of burlesque fans partnering with a local not for profit to take the risk to produce the festival this season. Our production budget is just over $18,000 and through both our ticket sales and our fundraising initiatives like this one we hope that the festival is successful enough to ensure the future of the event!
Every little bit donated to this campaign will help to bring the Glitterati to Saskatoon! This festival will also act as a fundraising inititative for the Broadway Theatre Charitable Org.
Other ways to show us your sparkly love!

If you are unable to make a financial donation at this time but would like to help out there are a number of ways to get involved! You can find more information on how to support the festival here https://saskatooninternationalburlesquefestival.com/index.php/support/

""Short"" Summary
""Family Business"" by Amanda Murphy will be playing from November 7th- 10th 2019 at 13th Street Repertory Theatre, which is a 66-seat Off-Off Broadway venue.
Amanda here. I started this company a year ago for one reason:

THERE ARE NOT ENOUGH FEMALE WRITER/ PRODUCERS IN NEW YORK (or anywhere), making original content- comedies, dramas, avant-garde circus acts- with FEMALE MAIN CHARACTERS. We should be HALF of the population of creators and right now we're about a quarter.
""Family Business"" is headed by an amazing all-female production team comprised of Amanda Murphy, Amanda Jayne, Francesca Day, and honorary female Christopher Matos.
<h3>What We Need &amp
In order to produce a play in a 66-seat Off-Off Broadway Theatre for one weekend, we need to finance the following:
<ul>
• Theatre Rental (13th Street Rep is VERY reasonably priced for a week rental, but still... it's New York): $2500
• Rehearsal space rental: $1500
• Set Design + Set Construction: $2000
• Costume/ Props: $1000
• Stage Management/ Crew: $1000
Everyone else is (AMAZINGLY) working for free but we WILL pay them if we exceed our fundraising goal.
The Impact

Our production staff, directors, writers, artists, and cast are entirely NEW talent heading off a NEW play. Starting from the ground floor isn't easy. We could make another remake of the Lion King which would guarantee us millions of dollars at the box office. We value ORIGINALITY, OPPORTUNITY, and GROWTH AS ARTISTS.
<h3>Risks &amp
Let's be honest. It's many of our first times producing an Off-Off-Broadway play. It could suck.

But guess what? It won't. First of all, we've got Francesca Day, who is the Goddess of Off-Off-Broadway. The rest of us have produced a half dozen short plays in NYC festivals this year alone. From the PIT Loft to the Tank, we're beloved everywhere. (We brag more on youupproductions.com)
We're also all four of us competent adults with theatre degrees. That lapse in judgement aside, we know what we're doing.
Other Ways You Can Help
Come and see the show!!!
Come to our launch party in at Secret Loft on September 10th!!
If you can't afford to donate money, donate time! We're gonna need box office and concessions stand staff in exchange for free admission. Email me at amanda@youupproductions.com if you're interested.

Written by Emerald Gearing and directed by Andrew Garcia, Weekend in Eden will make it’s World Premiere at the Hudson Guild Theater in Manhattan during New York Theater Festival’s SummerFest 2019. The full-length comedy was honored as a Semi-Finalist in the Austin Film Festival’s Stage Play competition (2018). Check out what AFF had to say about it!

“Weekend in Eden is a brilliantly comedic and honest three act play which pins sister against sister as they fight for a ring their grandmother said would bring them good fortune. The comedy, in combination with characters so human in their flaws, fears, and love, make this play a clear stand out in the competition. Bravo!”
– AFF Script Reader Notes

“This script gave me plenty of moments of laughter, imagination, and empathy, which ultimately made this work so well-rounded. It’s a well-crafted story about making the best decisions for ourselves and going through multiple hurdles just to get what we want.”                                                                          – AFF Script Reader Notes
“The play’s plot revolves around the contest for the pseudo-magical ring La Broma
column2: however, just as the sister’s fight is not truly about a ring, so too is the plot of this play not reduced to a simple conquest. Rather, through the battle for the ring, each character’s secrets, desires, and fears are uncovered and they most come to terms with those realities: both with themselves and each other…The humor in this piece is incredible and it’s so carefully balanced with serious conversations.”

column1: –AFF Script Reader Notes

Short Summary

This year, The Argentinian Prostitute Play will receive its world premiere at the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival - an honor granted only to 20 works out a massive pool of submissions. This premiere provides us with the opportunity to present a little-known moment of Jewish history to a wider audience that we've been researching and developing for nearly a year. It's time for us to tell this story on stage.
This will be a fully staged production with a cast of seven. The show runs about 90 minutes with no intermission.

Our cast will include: Nahar Aminov, Anja Avsharian (Beauty and the Beast, Player's Theatre), Mateo Ervin, Bruce Jimenez, Ben Natan (The Trial of Mrs. Surratt, Wandering Theatre Co.), Bella O'Brien, and Shawn Zylberberg.
What We Need
We need to raise a total of $7400, to be able fund the entire project from casting to rehearsal to the stage. Our budget breakdown is as follows:
Your generosity will help give the performance the attention to detail it needs, so I thank you in advance.
The Impact

Your impact will help culminate a process that began a year ago with a few sketches of potential scenes and characters into a full-blown production. We believe that this story - about a sex trade that lay underneath the Jewish community of Buenos Aires for over 70 years - is a valuable one that needs to be told. As of yet, all the material on this subject is purely scholarly. In a few short months, with your support, it will reach the New York stage and an audience who can experience this together in the communal form that is the theater.

If you aren't able to donate, please consider sharing our campaign to get the word out! One of the best ways to get attention is by word of mouth! The person who gets the most donations through shares will receive an invite to our opening night party!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h2 style=""text-align: center
column2:
>About the Show

The world is ending and you're invited to the last sh*tshow EVER! It's an indie-pop rager celebrating the delights and deceptions of existing, and it's the last one we've got. Why not go out with a bang?
column3:
>What We Need

Here's the breakdown of what we need in order to make this production as successful as possible:

We're looking to raise about $3,500 for our production of ...When the World is No Longer:. Your contribution will support basic needs such as compensation for our actors and production team, rehearsal space rentals, costumes, props, the whole sh-bang. Even if we don't make our goal, your contribution will still support our production, as any funds not received in donations will be coming out of the artists' personal finances. Thank you in advance for your kind donation!
column5:
>The Impact

In the past, An Incomplete List... was produced as part of the 2017 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. We produced this production on a $0 budget! All expenses were paid out of the pockets of the young artists making the art. After completing a successful sold-out run, Dante and the original cast and creative team were DETERMINED to continue the play's journey, reaching new artistic heights and new enthusiastic audiences. Since it's conception, this musical has been produced in partnership with Bloomsburg Theatre Ensemble as part of their summer season, and The University of the Arts as part of the Polyphone Festival for New &
column6: Emerging Musicals. Your generous contribution would assist us in producing the most ambitious New York City debut of this groundbreaking musical at none other than Ars Nova's All New Talent Festival.
column8:
>Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us by making a donation, don't sweat it! You can still help us by sharing this campaign with your friends and loved ones, and by seeing the show! (Because the show must go on!) Tickets for our show are selling fast, so buy yours here today! For more information on the show itself, check out our Facebook Event Page. For more information about Ars Nova, go to ArsNovaNYC.com

 

TICKET LINK: https://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/6.24

FACEBOOK EVENT PAGE: https://www.facebook.com/events/2292685064108240/

ARS NOVA WEBSITE: http://arsnovanyc.com

 

Cast and Creative Team

Dante Green, Garrett Allen, Lyell Hintz, Rose Slavin, Aigner Mizzelle, Steven Primero, Briyana Clarel, Alex Bechtel, Leigha Kato, Patrick Campbell, and Terran Scott.

 

PLAYWRIGHT'S WEBSITE: http://dantegreen.com

DIRECTOR WEBSITE: http://www.garrettcallen.com/

NEW GOAL: REACH A MINIMUM OF 4'000EUROS
<div><div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/xv4F9q1pdMU?autohide=1&amp
WHAT IS THE #YOMEENTACONO PROJECT?

#YoMeEntacono is a project that strives to bring the salsa and caleña culture around the world with a message of diversity and gender equality by supporting the empowerment and inclusion of both women and the LGBT community. We fight so that seeing a man dance in heels will not be an object of hatred anymore.
The project started in January 2019 in Cali, Colombia and has the ambition to grow around the world starting in European cities.
The project is currently trying to raise funds through a crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo: https://igg.me/at/yomeentacono
The goal is to raise a minimum of 4’000€ before the 28th of April 2019, in order to travel one month in June 2019, to two European cities.
WHERE IS #YOMEENTACONO PLANNING TO GO?
1.         Geneva, Switzerland – 6th to 20th of June 2019 (15 days)
Location for events &
2.         Paris, France – 20th of June to 3rd of July 2019 (15 days)
Location for events &
WHAT TO EXPECT FROM A #YOMEENTACONO EVENT?
<ul>

• An opening speech written by Miguel, talking about his own life experience growing up in a poor and dangerous neighborhood, facing homophobic and macho attacks throughout his life. He explains how salsa has positively influenced and encouraged acceptance and respect around the different forms of expressing himself.
• Projection of a short documentary produced by Charlotte, putting Cali on the map so that it gets recognition for its dance style and highlights its potential as a diverse global city.
• Inviting the audience to take part in an introduction class of salsa caleña.
• Closing the event by show of salsa caleña in heels choreographed by Miguel
The #YoMeEntacono events will be open to all public and free of charge.
OTHER GOALS PLANNED DURING THE TRIP
<ul>
• To hold several dance workshops including traditional and unique styles (Salsa, Pachanga Caleño Fusion, Chacha Caleño, Lady Style, Salsa Heels, etc.)
<li>To offer students private &amp
• To produce dance videos in heels in iconic places in Europe and spread the #YoMeEntacono challenge.
• To produce of a documentary to be released after the trip
• To start an online platform so that the #YoMeEntacono community can learn salsa caleña from anywhere in the world.
THE TEAM BEHIND THE PROJECT
Miguel Ferrerossa

Miguel is 23 and was born in the Aguablanca district, one of the most socially problematic sectors in Cali, Colombia. However, this community stands out for its joy transmitted through dance and music, where salsa is the protagonist.

Miguel began dancing professionally at the age of 17 and is now a professional dancer, instructor and choreographer. For the past four years, he has danced in Cali’s Salsódromo, a parade gathering the best professional salsa dancers in Cali and around the world.
A young man who, with his talent, skill and discipline reached a high level in a short amount of time. He excels as much dancing men’s style and women’s style.

He has performed in many shows and competed in international competitions such as the Mundial de Salsa de Cali. His teachers held him in such high esteem that he became the example for several groups of dancers in different schools. He helped many young girls and professional dancers grow artistically and always received positive feedback on his teaching methods.
He was a teacher in several dance schools up until January 2018, when he decided to start his own business as a personal brand.
From there on, he began his process of dancing in heels, wanting to promote this activity as a contribution to society to foster respect and acceptance of the LGBT community.
Charlotte Charbonnier

Charlotte is 30 and was born in Geneva, Switzerland. She graduated from a private journalism school in Paris and then worked for four years as a production manager for an audio-visual company in Switzerland.

However, Charlotte felt that the life she had was not satisfying enough and she felt the impulse to focus on herself. Therefore, she decided to find new life goals and ways to express her creativity. At 28, she decided to quit her job and started a course in video editing and graphic design.

She then started working as a freelancer, developing her own style. She takes care of everything from organizing to directing, and filming to editing her videos according to what her clients are looking for.

In April 2018, she decided to buy a one-way ticket to Havana, to embrace the love she has for dancing and traveling. She spent a month taking dance classes and practicing every day. She then found work volunteering in a salsa school in Cali, exchanging her videography skills for accommodation and salsa classes. Initially, she thought she’d only stay for a few weeks but little did she know, the Salsa Capital would end up being her home for the next 8 months.

It was Cali which gave her the opportunity to meet Miguel Ferrerossa, her salsa teacher. With whom she improves her dance technique daily and works hand-in-hand with the production and creation of #YoMeEntacono. Today she is the one behind the scenes, producing content and making this initiative more visible in order to achieve the goal of the proposed crowdfunding campaign.
THE START OF THE PROJECT #YOMEENTACONO

It was a night of June 2018 at an iconic bar in Cali, that Charlotte saw Miguel's unique style for the first time and decided to take classes with him. They had many things in common and quickly became very good friends. That's how they decided to put together his talent and her creativity to produce outstanding dance videos in iconic spots in the city.

In the midst of this desire to do something innovative and out of the ordinary, they had the idea of producing a video of Miguel dancing salsa caleña in heels. This was his chance to express one of his passions.

""We chose to go to an iconic place in the city, put on a costume and a pair of heels. When we arrived at the shooting location, an atmosphere of mockery was noticed in among some of the spectators who were there.""- Miguel said.

Noticing the reaction of the spectators, Miguel felt the lack of empathy that exists in Cali towards diversity and the negative impact it has on society. "" Salsa caleña is a rhythm that I love and adore, it's the dance of our grandparents and it’s traditional. That's why I decided to put on my high heels and dared to make this video with my team, to prove that as a society, we are evolving daily. And also, that it’s not acceptable that throughout 2017, more than 105 people have been killed because of this disease called homophobia.”

Together they want to demonstrate that it doesn't matter your background, your skin tone, your age, your preferences, whether you're straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender. Together, we can all join forces to deliver a message of tolerance and have a positive impact on society. Let’s make it a place where people dance to celebrate diversity without fear.
Link to the video : www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8aAqDRkqr0
THE FIRST STAGE OF #YOMEENTACONO IN CALI
The project #YoMeEntacono was officially launched in Cali, Colombia in January 2019, with the creation of two dance crews called the ""Ferrerossa Heels Crews"".

The groups going ranging from level basic-intermediate to intermediate-advanced, included both men and women who decided to dance in heels and give a voice to those who are scared of being crushed morally in a macho society.
After two months of workshops, the dance crew that gathered over 40 people each week, did a closing performance in Cali’s most iconic salsa bar “La Topa Tolondra”.
#YoMeEntacono’s team is now focusing on making the trip to Europe achievable, in order to grow on an international scale.
MEDIAS TALKING ABOUT THE PROJECT
Digital News Broadcast from the Noticiero 90 Minutos - Tuesday 8th of January 2019 – Report from minute 7:51 to 9:38
<div>
Digital News Broadcast from the Noticiero Noti5 - Thursday 21st de March 2019
https://youtu.be/LWWUaYAnCSc
WHY A CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN?

Living in a conservative country like Colombia, where several of your conceptions have been forged for many years by the church, makes it hard for the LGBT community or anyone who goes against tradition.

Up to this day, many of them suffer daily discrimination and in some cases, persecution. Studies show that transgender women pay the highest price as they have the biggest homicide rate and a life expectancy of only 35 years.

Miguel Ferrerossa comes from a low-income family where men are forbidden to act like women, let alone dance like them. However, he decided to swim against the current and through dancing found a supportive and caring community that accepts him as he is. Feeling supported and not judged by his sexual orientation, Miguel eventually decided to start the #YoMeEntacono movement to generate a positive impact on the city. To make it a place where a man can dance salsa caleña in heels and therefore open minds every step of the way and even encourage those who still don't dare to do it. An action perceived by many as a stupendous talent and an experiment to break taboos.

That's why we want to show a face of diversity from an evolving country and how it’s starting to accept the LGBTI community more and more. We are promoting ourselves as a gay-friendly destination and showing how the people, the joy, the rhythms, the gastronomy and the salsa that Cali has is a means to celebrate diversity, at a city level and soon a world level.

The funds we have gathered so far are not enough to cover the budget of this somewhat ambitious dream. That's why we decided to start a crowdfunding campaign with the goal of bringing more people together around the world who want to share our message and join our cause, by contributing financially or spreading the word.
The closer we get to our funding goal of 16'000Euros, the more we will be able to accomplish. Let's build this adventure together!
WHAT WILL THE FUNDS RAISED BE USED FOR?
Here’s why we need a minimum of 4’000€ to be able to fulfil this project:
• International Flights (for 2 people): between 2’000 - 3’000€
From Cali to Geneva - From Paris to Cali
• Train Tickets (for 2 people): between 80 - 200€
From Geneva to Paris
• Daily costs including food, transportation and miscellaneous:
Average of 60€ per day for 2 people
<ul>
• Accommodation in Geneva: No costs (staying with family)
• Accommodation in Paris: No costs (staying with friends)
We hope to spread this around the world, thank you very much for joining our community and sharing this message with your friends.
We would appreciate any kind of contribution, no matter how big or small, we believe that with everyone’s help we can make this dream a reality.
WHAT PERKS CAN YOU GET IN EXCHANGE FOR YOUR HELP?
In return for joining us on this journey, we are offering several perks including:
<ul>
• 5€ - An Instagram post of thanks just for you.
• 10€ - Have your name in the credits of the highlight movie we will produce during our trip.
• 20€ - A discount to one of Miguel's dance workshops in the city of your choice.
• 50€ - Miguel will do the dance challenge of your choice (in heels of course). You can choose the location and even the music, the video will be dedicated to you!
• 150€ - 3 different video tutorials to learn Salsa Caleña online.

• Special GIFT! For a contribution of 500€ you will get all of the perks mentioned above + the opportunity to follow the team for an entire day during their travel (including dinner + a private dance class + a video + exclusive behind the scenes content)
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
• Join the #YoMeEntacono community and share the project on your social medias, with your friends, family or people you think will be interested in supporting us.

• If you are a dance school, an LGBT association, a media or any kind of individual and want to join, sponsor the project, suggest ideas or collaborations you can contact us through this email: yomeentacono@gmail.com
Miguel Ferrerossa / +57 301 753 88 27 / Miguel Ferrerossa (Facebook) / @miguelferrerossa (Instagram) / yomeentacono@gmail.com
Charlotte Charbonnier / +41 76 679 59 27 (Whatsapp) / yomeentacono@gmail.com
Our Instagram account: @yomeentacono

Short Summary

We at Nerd &
column2: Tie love conventions, and we've decided to start a new one: the Nerd &
column3: Tie Expo. It's currently scheduled to take place September 23-25, 2016 at the Plaza Hotel &
column4:
Suites in Eau Claire, WI.

Trae, Pher and Nick have been running events most of their adult lives. Trae co-founded Wisconsin's longest running anime convention No Brand Con, and both he and Pher served terms as the organization's President and Convention Director.  Nick is no slouch either, having co-founded long running anime convention Daisho Con -- currently the second largest anime con in Wisconsin.

The three of us have been itching to come out of retirement and return to con running, so when No Brand Con announced they were relocating to the Wisconsin Dells earlier this year (as they've grown too large for Eau Claire), we decided that the time had finally arrived.

The Nerd &
column5:
Tie Expo aims to be the best con you've ever been to.  Besides Nick, Pher and Trae, we've assembled a team of veteran staffers, including former and current department heads from almost every con in Wisconsin. We're bringing in World 9 Gaming to run our video game room, Otaku Tonight is going to do some awesome events, and our table top room will be top notch.

We want to bring you the very best in anime, science fiction, and all sorts of gaming, period.

We also want to remain in Eau Claire for the long term, so with that in mind we're limiting attendance to 1,000 attendees.  By doing this, we'll be able to stay a size the venues in Eau Claire can support. We also think that smaller cons tend to be more fun anyway, so we think that this size will allow us to still be able to give you a top tier experience like larger cons while still creating a fun, inclusive community.

column1: What We Need &
column2:
What You GetRight now we can run the convention, and it'll be a lot of fun.  The reason we're running this campaign is we want to do more. Since we're limiting our size, and this is our first year, your contributions will let us invite more guests, have bigger events, and just make it as awesome as possible.

Your contribution is vital to making sure this convention will be as awesome as possible.

What you'll get in return are some great rewards -- from the basics like getting your name in our program guide to lifetime admission to any convention we ever run in the future. 

We also have some somewhat insane stuff listed because, frankly, why not?
No matter what though, we need your help to make sure that the Nerd &
column3:
Tie Expo can be as awesome as we hope it'll be.  With your contributions we can guarantee a safe future for geek-dom in the Chippewa Valley and Northwestern Wisconsin.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute even a little? We totally understand.  What you can do is help tell everyone about this campaign and the Nerd &
column4:
Tie Expo in general! 

Also, you can sign up for our mailing list so we can keep you up to date about everything else, like when regular preregistration opens.

As We Approach Our Goal

column1: We’ve
decided that, as we reach milestones on fund raising, that we’d put out
some… well… EXTRAS for your entertainment pleasure. Like songs. And
videos.
Here’s what you have to look forward to as we move along:

At $1000 - Trae will record an “Acoustic-ish” version of “Dear Enoby”
At $2000 - TO BE REVEALED LATER
At $3000 - Trae will record an “Acoustic-ish” version of “Ice Ice Baby”
At $4000 - TO BE REVEALED LATER
At $5000 - Trae will record an “Audiobook” version of the first ten chapters of “My Immortal”
You know you’re excited.  If we meet our goal, there will be additional stretch goals added obviously.
(What’s an ”Acoustic-ish” cover? Here’s one Trae did of Shake It Off as an example)

At $1000 - Trae will record an “Acoustic-ish” version of “Dear Enoby”At $2000 - TO BE REVEALED LATERAt $3000 - Trae will record an “Acoustic-ish” version of “Ice Ice Baby”At $4000 - TO BE REVEALED LATERAt $5000 - Trae will record an “Audiobook” version of the first ten chapters of “My Immortal”
You know you’re excited.  If we meet our goal, there will be additional stretch goals added obviously.

Short Summary

The dream of Brigham's Playhouse has been over 20 years in the making.  Owner Jamie Young left his 19 year career as a Professor of Musical Theatre to pursue his lifelong dream of opening a company that provides uplifting and edifying theatre. Brigham’s Playhouse believes in the power of live theatre and its ability to provide audiences and performing artists with life-changing experiences.

Brigham's Playhouse would  not be possible without the continuous support we have received from our families, friends, patrons, and community members. We want to keep the dream going in providing an uplifting theatre experience. Any amount pledged will help continue  this dream!
What We Need &

column2: >Just like every small playhouse, costs are very high to produce high quality theatre productions.  We rely on contributions from those who believe in our philosophy and the power that quality theatre, such as what is produced at Brigham's Playhouse, has to change lives.
>      We have previously operated only as a privately funded company, but under the umbrella of A.R.T.S. Inc. (a 501 (c)3 non-profit), we can now accept tax- deductible donations as well.

>         $42,000 in pledged donations would help Brigham's Playhouse with the cost of  licenses to produce the upcoming season, construction of the sets and costumes, obtaining props, securing directors and designers for each show, and all of the other production aspects that go into running and operating a theatre company.

column1:
• Regardless of the amount we raise, all of the funds (after indiegogo fees) will be donated to Brigham's Playhouse to go toward the expenses listed above. 

    • The Impact

    • Brigham's Playhouse is the only professional theatre company operating in Washington, UT and one of only a few within the immediate area. Our mission to provide wholesome, affordable, and professional entertainment impacts the community in a positive way. 
    • Brigham's Playhouse has provided 2 successful seasons of quality entertainment and has become an integral part of the community in Southern Utah. There is a sense of belonging and purpose for all who participate in the experience whether youth or senior citizen, whether paid professional or fantastic community volunteer
column2:
whether as a patron in the audience or performer on our stage. 

Risks &

column1: • As with any new business, the first few years are the hardest financially. Being a new company in the area has provided several challenges, such as the need to build exposure and name recognition. As we continue to grow, we are met with the challenge of competing with other great options that local theatre lovers have to choose from. It can be hard to predict and plan for how many patrons we will have from show to show.

• Contributing to a new entity may seem like a risk, but we have been able to overcome these hurdles for the past 21 months we have been in operation, and look forward to being a great theatre company for years to come!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution right now, please consider helping us in these other ways!

  • Attend Brigham's Playhouse performances. Showtimes are listed on our website @ www.brighamsplayhouse.com 
  • Tell your friends! If you have seen a show at Brigham's Playhouse, or are excited about the work we are doing here... Share! Many of our audience members come from word-of-mouth recommendations, which helps our business to grow!
• Like and share our posts on social media.

• Put us in contact with business owners who you feel might make great sponsors for Brigham's Playhouse. Share with those business owners why sponsoring us would benefit their business! Contact us if you'd like to pick up a sponsorship packet.

Brigham's Playhouse would  not be possible without the continuous support we have received from our families, friends, patrons, and community members. We want to keep the dream going in providing an uplifting theatre experience. Any amount pledged will help continue  this dream!
What We Need & What You Get

Just like every small playhouse, costs are very high to produce high quality theatre productions.  We rely on contributions from those who believe in our philosophy and the power that quality theatre, such as what is produced at Brigham's Playhouse, has to change lives.
We have previously operated only as a privately funded company, but under the umbrella of A.R.T.S. Inc. (a 501 (c)3 non-profit), we can now accept tax- deductible donations as well.

$42,000 in pledged donations would help Brigham's Playhouse with the cost of  licenses to produce the upcoming season, construction of the sets and costumes, obtaining props, securing directors and designers for each show, and all of the other production aspects that go into running and operating a theatre company.

column1: Amikor
szívével lát az ember
Magyarország
az az ország, amely Európa közepén fekszik és sokak szerint itt
lüktet a Föld Szívcsakrája. Azé a bolygóé, amely minden
embernek otthont ad, mégis egyik ember elveszi a másik otthonát,
ételét, életét, családját. Mi, magyarok, tudjuk, milyen az,
amikor elveszik otthonunkat és egy napon idegenként ébredünk
saját szülőföldünkön.
És
mégis mi vagyunk azok, akik drótkerítést húzunk rettegő emberek
arca elé. Mi vagyunk azok, akik a Legvidámabb Barakk-ból Európa
szégyenfoltja lettünk. Mi lettünk azok, akik hivatalossá tettük
a gyűlöletet és kirekesztést.
Nem,
nem mi lettünk azok! Mi nem vagyunk azonosak azokkal, akik
belerúgnának a földön fekvőkbe.
Mi azok vagyunk, akik a szívünkkel
látunk és nem a félelmeinken keresztül sandítunk a világra. Mi
vagyunk azok, akik érzik, értik a veszélyt és csapdát, ami ránk
és Európára leselkedik és mégis Emberek tudunk maradni.
A
szívünkkel látunk és az olyan részletek felett elsiklik a
figyelmünk, hogy az a szögesdrót kerítés pontosan hány méter a
mai napon. Ezért
lett az, hogy 275.000 dollárt gyűjtünk 175.000 helyett. Az
Egyetemes Bölcsesség megmutatta, mire vezet az, amikor az ember a
szívével lát és nem az egójával. ""Véletlenül""
többet kezdtünk gyűjteni, mint amennyi az eredeti szándékunk
volt. Ennek ereje van. Nem csináljuk vissza

és nem javítjuk ki. Mert mi a szívünkkel látjuk: a lényeget.


When you see with your heart

Hungary is a country in the center of Europe, and many say it is the place where throbs the Earth's Heart Chakra. That of the planet which gives home to all human beings, and yet, people take each other's homes, food, lives or families. We, Hungarians, know what it is like, when our homes are taken from us and when out of the blue we wake up as strangers in our own motherland.

And still, we are the ones pulling barbwire fences in front of the faces of terrified people. We are the ones, who turned from being the Happiest Barrack to Europe's disgrace. We became the ones who made hate and exclusion official. 

No, we didn't! We are not of one mind with those who would kick someone already down. We are the ones, who can see with their hearts, and are not peering out at the world through the lense of our fears. We are the ones, who feel and understand the danger and the trap that looms over us and over Europe, and yet we are able to remain Human.

We see with our hearts, and our eyes skip over details like how many meters wide the barbwire fence is exactly on this day. That is why we are collecting 275,000 dollars instead of 175,000. Universal Wisdom shows us the way, when people see with their hearts, instead of their egos. We ""accidentally"" started collecting more than was our original intent. That is powerful. We will not undo it and we will not rectify it. Because we see with our hearts: we see what matters.

Our answer to 275,000 meters of barbwire is 275,000 dollars of love.
