WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE WANT TO DO /// KIM JESTEŚMY I CO CHCEMY ZROBIĆ

Warsaw Ballet is a new neoclassical dance company based in Poland. As new as it is it already gave hope and motivation to many young dancers. It is project based on private funds without any goverment support which is why we need financial support from sponsors and patrons of art. The money that we will raise will go to our first production ""OF LOVE - ballet evening"" as we need to produce costumes, set design, rent a Theater, buy professional ballet floor for theater's stage and we will also need some funds for promoting what we do in media. 

Ballet in Poland is not and easy field, it is not well promoted and there are few places where you can actually see ballet spectacles. By our project we want to make a change by creating something that has never been in Poland before - private ballet company. At the same time we want to create new place for young dancers and choreographers

///

Warsaw Ballet jest nowym, polskim zespołem baletu neoklasycznego. Choć jest nowy to jednak już wielu tancerzom dał nadzieję oraz motywację. Jest to projekt, który opiera się na prywatnych funduszach bez wsparcia ze strony rządu lub jakiejkolwiek innej instytucji publicznej i właśnie dlatego też potrzebujemy finansowej pomocy ze strony sponsorów oraz mecenasów sztuki. Pieniądze, które teraz zbierzemy zostaną wykorzystane do naszej pierwszej produkcji ""OF LOVE - wieczór baletowy"" i zostaną przeznaczone na produkcję kostiumów, scenografii, wynajem teatru oraz profesjonalną podłogę baletową i promocję w mediach. 

Balet w Polsce jest w dość trudnej sytuacji, nie jest wystarczająco dobrze promowany i istnieje naprawdę niewiele miejsc, w których można zobaczyć spektakle baletowe. Naszym projektem chcemy coś zmienić i stworzyć coś co do tej pory nie miało miejsca w Polsce - prywatny zespół baletowy. Chcemy jednocześnie stworzyć miejsce pracy dla młodych tancerzy oraz choreografów

ABOUT FOUNDER OF WARSAW BALLET /// O ZAŁOŻYCIELCE WARSAW BALLET

Founder of Warsaw Ballet - Natalia Maria Wojciechowska is former soloist with Polish National Theater, but she decided to quit PNB and explore how to create business and make her vision come true. In 3 years after changing her life upside down she brought Warsaw Ballet to life and hopefully with your kind support Warsaw Ballet will have it's very first premiere in June.


///


Założycielka Warsaw Ballet - Natalia Maria Wojciechowska jest byłą solistką Polskiego Baletu Narodowego, ale postanowiła rzucić tę posadę by nauczyć się, jak założyć oraz prowadzić własny biznes i uczynić swoją wizję realną. W trzy lata po radykalnej zmianie w swoim życiu założyła Warsaw Ballet i ten oto zespół dzięki Waszemu wsparciu będzie miał swoją pierwszą premierę w czerwcu.

More about Natalia and her life:

Born on 29th of January 1983 in Warsaw/Poland. A graduate of John Neumeier Hamburg Ballet School. While still just a student, she danced the leading role in “The Nutcracker” by John Neumeier at the prestigious Nijinsky Gala in Hamburg in 2001. She attended the State Ballet School in Warsaw up to 1999. As a student in Poland she was twice a prize-winner of the National Dance Competition in Gdańsk, coming third in the junior category in 1997, and first in the senior category in 1999. As a finalist she received a scholarship at the Prix de Lausanne International Dance Competition in January 1999, which enabled her to go to the prestigious Hamburg Ballet School.

She has twice received a Hapag Lloyd a scholarship for extremely talented youth as well as other scholarships, including one from National Found for Children. She has worked with many great choreographers, including: John Neumeier, Mats Ek, Maurice Bejart and Kevin, Kevin Haigen, Aleksiej Ratmansky, Emil Wesołowski and Krzysztof Pastor. After graduating form the Hamburg Ballet School she joined Neumeier’s Ballet Company, and in her very first season danced many ensemble parts and small solos in “Giselle”, :Illusions – Like Swan Lake”. “Nijinsky” and many other productions, she was also given a part of Olimpia in “Lady of Camellias”. In 2003-2006 she mainly worked with the ROMA Musical Theater and Warsaw Operetta Theater as a soloist. She joined the National Opera Ballet Company in the season 2006/2007 – 2010/11, to work on one of the greatest parts in the classical repertoire – Odette/Odile in “Swan Lake”. Her debut in this part took place in March 2007. In june 2007 she debuted as Tatiana in John Cranko’s “Onegin”. As of September 2007 she is a soloist of the Polish National Ballet. Since then she danced many interesting and challenging parts : Anna in “Anna Karenina” by A.Ratmansky, Eurydyka in “Kurt Weill” by K.Pastor, soloist in “Concerto Barocco” by G.Balanchine, Winter Fairy in “Cinderella” by F.Ashton and many more.In 2003-2005 she mostly worked as dance soloist at Musical Theater Roma creating one of most fampus musical dancing parts – white cat Victoria in „Cats”In 2005 her first book was published „ Making off Dance of the Vampites of Roman Polański”In season 2006/7 she was a dance soloists at Operetta Mazovia were she created many dancing parts. In 2009 she created Pole Dance Project – first dance agency with main profile pole dance – later on Pole Dance Project became dance studio and agency ( from 2013 Pole Dance Project has new owners). In 2011 she became first vice champion in pole dancing in Poland. In 2011 she created Pole Dance Cup – Interantional Pole Dance Competition which she artisticly organized in 2011 and 2013 ( now she is no longer involved). In 2012 as hobby she founded pole Sport Association Poland and organized first Pole Dance Championships in Poland. In 2013 she became teacher at Dance Academy Etoile teaching her author programmes. In 2014 she founded Neoclassica Foundation which supports neoclassical dance art Same year she founded Ballet Center Neoclassica and Warsaw Ballet which she is dancer, director and choreografer of. Apart from all that she is well know international stretching instructor recognized as NATALIA STRETCHES - www.facebook.com/Natalia.stretches and writer of stretching blog - www.natalistretches.blogspot.com


ABOUT ""OF LOVE - BALLET EVENING"" /// O ""OF LOVE""


Natalia Maria Wojciechowskahad had this idea about bringing few choreographers and dancers together to show various kinds of LOVE for many years and now she is bringing it to life.

OF LOVE will be a cycle of ballet evenings choreographed by various artists for Warsaw Ballet.

First edition ""OF LOVE"" will be choreographed by Natalia herself and Bartek Woszczyński.

- ""Unlike any"" - chor.Natalia Maria Wojciechowska, music:Arvo Part, Bach, Satie, Barber

UNLIKE ANY is one act neoclassical ballet, which in very simple form, yet with some twists shows serach, finding and giving in LOVE. Natalia dedicates this ballet to love of her life - her husband thanks to whom she was born again and without whom she still would be a very lonely drop. 

- ""................."" chor. Bartek Woszczyński, music: Arvo Part

more details about Bartek's piece soon

The message of this ballet evening is very simple, pure nad innocent - LOVE


///

Natalia zarys pomysłu by zebrać choreografów oraz tancerzy aby w tańcu pokazać różne odcienie miłości nosiła w głowie wiele lat , a teraz nadaję temu pomysłowi realnych barw

OF LOVE będzie cyklem wieczorów baletowych choreografowanych przez różnych artystów dla Warsaw Ballet.

Choreografami pierwszej edycji OF LOVE będzie Natalia oraz Bartek Woszczyński

- ""Unlike any"" - chor.Natalia Maria Wojciechowska, muzyka: Arvo Part, Bach, Satie, Barber

UNLIKE ANY to jednoaktowy balet utrzymany w stylu tańca neoklasycznego. Inspirowany życiem artystki w ascetycznej acz niecodziennej formie opowiada o poszukiwaniu, spotkaniu oraz oddaniu się miłości.
column2: >Natalia dedykuje ten balet miłości swojego życia - swojemu mężowi, dzięki któremu narodziła się na nowo i bez którego nadal byłabym samotną kroplą.
column3:
>- ""..............."" chor.Bartek Woszczyński, music Arvo Part

opis wkrótce

Przesłanie tego wieczoru baletowego jest bardzo proste, bez podtekstów oraz niewinne - MIŁOŚĆ


WHAT WE NEED AND HOW MUCH /// I CZEGO POTRZEBUJEMY I ILE


To make it easier we will describe it in points:

1. Costumes - 350 USD

2. Set design - 400 USD

3. Ballet floor - 1750 USD

4. Renting a Theater - 1000 USD

Of course there are many other expenses, but we want to add some of our private money to it - we do not want to ask for everything.

///

Najprościej będzie ująć to w punktach:

1. Kostiumy - 350 USD

2. Scenografia - 400 USD

3. Podłoga baletowa - 1750 USD

4. Wynajem teatru - 1000 USD

Oczywiście są i inne wydatki, ale nie chcemy prosić o wszystko, ponieważ chcemy część finansować z własnej kieszeni


WHAT WILL YOU GET/// CO OTRZYMACIE?


For 50 USD donation - a title of silver sponsor

For 100 USD donationa - a title of silver sponsor and 1 ticket to the premiere

For 500 and more USD - a title of gold sponsor and 5 tickets to the premiere

///


Za 50 USD - tytuł srebrnego sponsora

Za 100 USD - tytuł srebrnego sponsora oraz 1 bilet na premierę

Za 5000 USD - tytuł złotego sponsora oraz 5 biletów na premierę


WHAT WILL WE DO IF WE WILL NOT RAISE FULL AMOUNT /// CO ZROBIMY JEŚLI NIE ZBIERZEMY TEK KWOTY


If we will not raise enough money we will keep on searching ( as we do all the time)  for other sources of financial support and we WILL (no matter what) stage our spectacle ""OF LOVE - ballet evening"", yet maybe a bit later than in June

If you have any questions, please write to dance foundation of Natalia Maria Wojciechowska - Neoclassica Foundation (www.neoclassica.pl ) - she will respond to all emails:

info@neoclassica.pl


///


Jeśli nie zbierzemy tej kwoty będziemy nadal szukać (jak to stale czynimy) innych form finansowania i bez względu na trudności i tak wystawimy wieczór baletowy ""OF LOVE"", tylko, że może ciut później niż w czerwcu


Jeśli macie jakiekolwiek pytania kontaktujcie się bezpośrednio z Natalią przez jej Fundację - Fundacja Neoclassica - www.neoclassica.pl:

info@neoclassica.pl 

","WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE WANT TO DO /// KIM JESTEŚMY I CO CHCEMY ZROBIĆWarsaw Ballet is a new neoclassical dance company based in Poland. As new as it is it already gave hope and motivation to many young dancers. It is project based on private funds without any goverment support which is why we need financial support from sponsors and patrons of art. The money that we will raise will go to our first production ""OF LOVE - ballet evening"" as we need to produce costumes, set design, rent a Theater, buy professional ballet floor for theater's stage and we will also need some funds for promoting what we do in media. Ballet in Poland is not and easy field, it is not well promoted and there are few places where you can actually see ballet spectacles. By our project we want to make a change by creating something that has never been in Poland before - private ballet company. At the same time we want to create new place for young dancers and choreographers///Warsaw Ballet jest nowym, polskim zespołem baletu neoklasycznego. About MDC

Menagerie Dance Collective is an aspiring dance company and movement project that currently does not exist for the dancer. Dancers pursue personal artistry as a soloist while also performing with the group or collective.  This approach provides the dancer with rich personal and shared experiences that otherwise do not exist. Please help us share this opportunity.

column5: >From our audience: ""Spending time with ""Menagerie"" touches the observer, moves one to tears, and awakens a deeper sense of human connection. That sense of community, that sense of belonging, even if fleeting

column1: <b style=""background-color: initial
<ul>

• The choreographer/director has created an exclusive new format from which dancers can grow, learn and work exponentially!
  • You will support our desire to share this project with diverse audiences. Our first goal is to travel to Utah to perform in a choreography festival. Ms. Jessica Haslip of Utah, a dancer with Menagerie says ""This is something dancers are looking for and do not know it"".
By making any contribution to Menagerie, you will assist us in realizing multiple, ongoing dreams for our members.
• Each are on personal journeys in dance art, we also desire conscious connections support the collective.
• Our audiences deserve SOMETHING SPECIAL FOR SPENDING TIME WITH US.
<li>
Our travel to and our performance in Utah will have a dramatically positive impact for us and will also provide us with momentum into the future !

column2: >Jessica Haslip -The Rocky Mountain Choreography Festival has been a great experience for me in the past. It has been amazing to see choreographers from around the United States come together to share their innovative and creative approaches to dance. This year, I am excited to return performing with Menagerie from Albuquerque, NM. and to share this beautiful vision.

>The choreographer and this group of dancers have helped me to reignite and even surpass the feelings I have for dance. Spontaneous, in depth, affirming and freeing are a few words I would use to describe the experience. 

How You Will Help

column1: <li>
We are seeking $5,000 in contributions to cover airfare, housing, meals, honorariums for the dancers who will miss work to perform at the festival, costumes, t-shirts and studio rental.

• Be sure to review Perks !
  • Funds exceeding $5,000 will allow us to perform locally while continuing to pursue performance opportunities in Utah followed by Arizona, New York and San Francisco.

    • The Impact

• This project allows dancers an opportunity that 95% of dancers NEVER see in their career. 
  • Our director has produced more than 35 of these events. Audiences love the format he has designed. 
  • You will be directly supporting each of their journeys in realizing their full potential as a dance artist.
• College graduates from University of Arizona, Utah State, Weber State, as well as dancers from Kansas City Ballet, Joffrey, and many other aspiring professionals have benefited of this process.

• Your contribution will help us continue and share this opportunity.

    • Challenges

    As we are days from traveling
column2:
it is important we secure the funds as soon as possible. 

  • We need your support to arrive at our financial goals quickly.
  • We would GREATLY appreciate any and all support and contributions. Thank you in advance !

Other Ways You Can Help


  • We understand that some are unable to contribute. You can still be of great assistance by sharing our link with persons you feel would be interested in supporting our vision.
  • Allow the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page to assist you !

What We're Up To

column2: >Out of the box? THERE IS NO BOX. We recycled the box. The box got disassembled and made into cardboard origami. Now this box has facets, this box has options. Now this box is human.

WHY ROMEO &

column2: Juliet is a tale of love's triumph over violence and fear
column3: Shakespeare distills this down to its archetypal essence. Kind of a big deal, right?

column1: OK COOL BUT WAIT WHO ARE YOU?
We are a motley band of professional actors eager to make really killer theatre. For free. For you.

What We're Raising and Why 

  • $10,000 to pay all 16 artists on the team. Not a luxurious sum, but a very modest compensation for their time. Because we all have rent to pay and mouths to feed. And because artists work so flipping hard.
• This is a free offering to the public! We are asking for gifts from those who can give, so that everyone can come to the theatre, regardless of income.
• Anything raised over the goal will be split with the Oakland Omni Commons.

• And hey! March 27th and 28th are benefit performances for the Omni: any donations received at that performance will be give to the Omni so they can keep the lights on and the doors open for all of Oakland.
<ul>

No Cash? That's OK!

  • Spread the word! Share Share Share.
• COME SEE THE PLAY! Bring a friend, bring ten friends! Bring your grandmother and her dog. Bring your neighbor and that guy you met at the laundromat. Come. Celebrate. Enjoy.
","What We're Up To
THE TEAM:
Out of the box? THERE IS NO BOX. We recycled the box. The box got disassembled and made into cardboard origami. Now this box has facets, this box has options. Now this box is human.

Director: Maryssa Wanlass*Stage Manager: Michael Truman Cavanaugh*Instigator / Rabble Rouser: Caitlyn LouchardFight Director: Carla PantojaDramaturg / Oracle: Nick MedinaMarketing Wizard: Melissa Nigro

Juliet: Beth WilmurtRomeo: Caitlyn LouchardFriar Lawrence: Lizzie Calogero*Nurse: Michael Patrick Gafney*Mercutio: Kelli Crump*Tybalt: Melissa Ortiz*Lady Capulet: Carla Pantoja*Lord Capulet: Mary Baird*Peter: Phil WongParis: Rotimi Agbabiaka*Friar John / Abraham: Alexis WilsonBenvolio: Maria MarquisPrince: Jesse Caldwell*
*Member, Actor's Equity Association
WHY ROMEO & JULIET?
Romeo & Juliet is a tale of love's triumph over violence and fear
column2: Shakespeare distills this down to its archetypal essence. Kind of a big deal, right?

CONSUMING KINETICS DANCE COMPANY

CKDC offers a wide variety of dance classes to the public for every age and every technical level. It's never too late or too early to learn how to dance. CKDC is the only dance company in the St. Louis area that specializes in drop in classes for busy professionals. We offer a flexible schedule that fits into yours.
CKDC is a 501(c)3 charitable corporation. All classes offered by our company of dancers and dance educators are the support structure for our performance company. We thank you for your contributions.

We value motion as a mutual experience shared between all people. We embrace individuals who seek to live a balanced life through art and more specifically, dance. We provide a sanctuary for artists to reveal or rediscover their potential as movers. By offering a flexible curriculum, we strengthen the practice of dance and choreography while creating opportunities to pursue careers in the performing arts.

What We Need

Funds to rent a venue and produce a full length concert this fall 2015

  • Dancers' salaries

• Costumes
  • Tech and stage crew
  • Venue renting and expenses

• Equipment rental such as lights, backstage communication and installation design 

    • The Impact

    CKDC is a growing professional dance company in St. Louis that provides competitive salaries for full time artists and dancers. CKDC also offers a school of dance for youth and adults where dozens of scholarships are awarded each semester.

    • Creates employment opportunities for artists in your community 
    • Provides education for students of all ages 

    Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Raising the funds necessary to rent a venue for performances is one of the biggest obstacles for dance companies around the world. Sponsoring CKDC will help cover the expense of producing a show and allow the company to pay the artists for their rehearsal and performance time. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the financial ability to fund our campaign, simply share it with your friends and family or on social media. The more awareness, the more exposure, the better for our company of artists.

Co-Artistic Directors Erin McDonough and Taylor Wasmer established Austin Allegro Dance in 2014. AAD is an innovative, multimedia contemporary dance company, working to bring vibrant and authentic dance to all audiences.

AAD’s dancers come from strong technical backgrounds in dance, and use formal training in performances that aim to push boundaries of art and dance. AAD is known for doing site specific performances around Austin. Our site specific work is created in response to a particular place, site, inspired by its architecture/design, the history and current use.

Austin Allegro Dance Company is excited to be entering into their FIRST season!!! We have HUGE dreams and goals for our company and we can’t do it without your help! Our aspiring show will be this summer in June &
column2: July 2015. In order for this to happen, we must receive funding!

column1: Let us give you a brief break down of the cost for our upcoming season:
Venue: $2,000
Lighting design: $2,000
Costume: $1,000
Set design: $1,500

Dancer’s compensation (7 dancers + guest artists): $5,000 Each of our dancers commits many hours to rehearsal and getting a show ready. We believe it is important to compensate the dancers for the time and effort that they put into the show. This would give us roughly $550 per dancer. 

Videographer/photographer of performances: $500
Choreographer/producer: $500
Front of House Manager: $350

Supplementary rehearsal space: $300

**If we do not reach our entire goal, we will have to downsize in our venue rental and all procedes will go to a smaller production. 

The Impact:

Austin Allegro Dance Company is passionate about giving back to the community. At our show we will be hosting a silent auction, 50% of the proceeds will be DONATED to Leap of Joy. Leap of Joy is a non-profit organization empowering young people through dance and theater arts. Through grants and private donations they are able to offer after school programming for elementary aged students at NO COST to they families. Check them out at:  http://www.leapofjoy.org
How can I support Austin Allegro Dance Company?
That is so kind of you to ask!!!
1) MAKE A PLEDGE (that's why you've read this far, right?!) - look to the right for more information on what you'll get for your contribution.
2) SHARE THIS MESSAGE - Email, Facebook, Twitter - every action counts!
3) FOLLOW US ON SOCIAL MEDIA
<div>
http://www.austinallegrodance.com
https://www.facebook.com/allegrodanceaustin?ref=hl
http://instagram.com/aad_company/
<div>
<div>

More about Taylor:

Taylor completed her undergraduate work at Texas State University graduating with honors, Magna Cum Laude, with her BFA in Dance. At Texas State she was a student teacher and member of Merge Dance Company. Her time with Merge Dance Company opened up many performance opportunities as well as a chance to work with various international choreographers. Through the years Taylor has worked to combine her two biggest passions which are performing arts &
column2: service. These passions have taken her all around the world from Turkey, Thailand, Greece, South Africa, Israel and more! Taylor completed a Summer Profession Semester at Broadway Dance Center in New York City where she grew exponentially as an artist and performer while being trained in contemporary, ballet, jazz.  She is currently teaching classes at Dance Xplosion as well as Illusion Dance Center. She plans to continue building the career that she’s always dreamed of by performing, choreographing, teaching and traveling.

column1: xoxo, Taylor
<div>

More about Erin: 

Erin grew up in North Adams, Massachusetts where she received formal training at Berkshire Dance Theater and Canterella School of Dance. During these early years, Erin completed the Cechetti Ballet Exams and attended NADAA (National Alliance of Dance and the Affiliated Arts). Soon after, Erin attended Plymouth State University and graduated Summa Cum Laude with a degree in Education and Dance. While at Plymouth, Erin performed in numerous Contemporary Dance Ensembles and had the opportunity to perform under the direction of Prometheus Dance Company, Amy Marshall Dance Company, and Pamela Pietro (NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts). She received anonymous dance scholarships and received the Contemporary Dance Ensemble Award in her senior year. After graduating, Erin danced for IMPACT Dance Company (Boston), and Tributary Dance Company (New England). Erin has a deep passion for dance and is looking forward to AAD's first season!
xoxo, Erin

Imagine, 40 years in the future, a species of extraterrestrials have invaded Earth.  Humanity fights back, bravely uniting nations under the flag of an international defense force. 

5 years after the initial invasion, enter our protagonist, Reagan.  A little bit irresponsible, and a little bit impulsive, Reagan is a 22 year old college drop out without much to do except try to keep her part time job and sit at home watching TV.   After seeing a rather persuasive recruitment ad, she joins the international defense force and elects to start training immediately. 

The story of Reagan's time in the Demon Wars is going to be told through song and dance..well not dance exactly, but highly choreographed action sequences involving lots of phaser guns and swords and cyborgs, etc. Sci- fi theater is already a challenge to stage.  Add music and choreography and you've got my senior project- Cythraul. 

My name's Isabella D'Esposito, and I'm the playwright, composer and lyricist.   This script is my senior project at Purchase College, where I'll be graduating in May 2015.  

My creative team-  Ash Zeitler (Lighting Design/Projection), Lei-Lei Bavoil (Fight Direction),  Vicky Butler (Costume Design), Victoria Blum (Assistant Director) and Kevin Downing

AND 

Our Wonderful Cast- 

Jasmine Castronuovo, Billy Manton, Anjelica Mitilisky, Ethan Steers, Catherine Pelkey, Emma Meyers, Kara Diresta, and Kevin Downing

Bard &
based theatre company dedicated to creating beautiful, simply staged shows with
a touch of levity.
Shakespeare's plays have always used humor and passion to
appeal to audience members from all walks of life.  In March 2015 Bard &amp
tradition with Hamlet, Shakespeare's classic tragedy of revenge and self doubt
- complete with foam swords, quick changes, and one very drunk actor
desperately trying to remember the words.
Six actors will memorize and rehearse a classic play. Then, in front of
the audience at the top of the show, one actor will shoot back enough whiskey
to make things challenging for everyone onstage.  What happens next is anyone's guess.
We hope you will help us in bringing this joyful production
to the stage.  We are working hard to
create quality theatre on a very low budget so every dollar counts and 100% of
funds go toward production costs.
OTHER WAYS TO HELP
Spread the word!  If
you're as excited about this project as we are, tell a friend.  Tell all your friends.  Tell a stranger and maybe you'll make a new
friend.  A full house is our favorite
kind of support.
Lend us a hand! Or chair! Or dagger!  Check out our Facebook page for prop and set
requests.  That ugly vase sitting in your
basement might be just what we need.
Share this campaign!  It's
okay if you don't have the money to help out right now.  We're theatre people - we understand!  Share this campaign to help us be seen by those
who can donate.

Founded by Ashley Porcuincula and the founder/director of the Sacramento Horror Film Festival, Tim Meunier, in 2009, Amber's Sweets has strived to be the alternate theatre going experience.

Amber's Sweets was the first in the world to shadow cast the ""best worst movie"" Troll 2 in 2014. Amber's Sweets resume also includes The Rocky Horror Picture Show, REPO! The Genetic Opera, The Devil's Carnival, Dr. Horrible's Sing-Alog Blog, and Clue.

Amber's Sweets next goal is to produce a tribute show for The Little Shop of Horrors. Part film, part revue, part sing-along, Amber's Sweets The Little Shop of Horrors Tribue Show aims to take center stage during the 9th Annual Sacramento Horror Film Festival in the fall of 2015.

We need your help to raise $1500.

The funds will be used to pay for materials and labor to build all 4 Audrey II puppets for the tribute show. We've looked into renting all 4 Audrey 2s, but for our ""one night only"" needs, it is not cost effective.

If we do not meet our goal, we will need to post pone the tribute show.

Next to our Evil Dead production we have planned, The Little Shop of Horrors is at the top of the list as shows requested for us to produce by our fans.

When you contribute to the Sacramento Horror Film Festival and Amber's Sweets, you are not contributed to a mass produced product. You are contributing to an event that is a labor of love for so many cult movie fans and volunteers. Your contributions help bring to life a special, one of a kind event that combines performance art, comedy, puppetry, burlesque, and more to pay tribute to a film and musical that has inspired and brought so much to cult movie fans everywhere.

Contribute today and you'll get the most out of every perk we have to offer.

More importantly, you'll help art come to life.

Thank you

-Tim Meunier, Producer - Amber's Sweets, Owner/Director- Sacramento Horror Film Festival

OUR STORY
We are The Bonfire Makers,  a brand spankin' new (small, but growing) Oakland based theatre company with a big vision to bring together our diverse Bay Area community by creating theatre that directly responds to our present socio-political landscape. Our current project, WE GO BOOM, explores the impact of the tech industry on Oakland specifically. The piece examines both the tech industry's role in displacing black and brown residents and also how technology can help us create a more just and positive world.  By exploring what is happening now in our community, we ask the question:  where do we go from here? The play is a woven tapestry of interviews, personal stories, physical improvisation, and super awesome original music. 
The Bonfire Makers is made up of 6 performers, our awesome production team, and our magnificent Composer. We are:
Melissa Carter, Co-Founder  and performer
Sonia Decker, Co-Founder and performer
Georgina Stuart Oram, Events Coordinator and Marketing Director

Jennifer Fong, Stage Manager 
Alex Van Gils, Composer 
Our Immensely Talented Ensemble: 
Tierra Allen
What We Need &
Budget:  $5,000
• Space/ Performance Rental plus insurance= $3,552
• Administrative Costs (website maintenance and administrative printing)= $123
• Marketing Costs (Marketing Director stipend plus printing costs for flyers and posters)= $225
• Artistic Costs (Performer stipends, costumes, and scenic elements)=$700
• Other Costs (Performance Concessions, fundraising costs, and estimated taxes)=$400
• If you support We Go Boom, you'll be part of the team and enjoy free tickets, recording of our original score, and more!
• If we do not meet the entirety of our fundraising goal, the money that we make will go first to paying the artists and then to space rental.
• If we exceed our goal, the money will go into planning for the future and deepening community relationships.

The Impact

This show will create vital dialogue about the massive presence of the tech industry in the Bay Area.  Our central questions include:
Why is there a lack of diversity in the tech industry?
How can the presence of the tech industry positively benefit long time Oakland residents?
How is technology changing the way that we communicate an interact with our communities?
What positive tools does technology offer us?  How can we use technology to transform our current oppressive system?
We will have a facilitated discussion about these questions after each of our 6 performances to create community dialogue and inspire continued conversation.
<ul>

• We've been working on this show for over a year. Co-Founders Melissa Carter and Sonia Decker took a workshop version of We Go Boom to the CrisisArt Festival in Arezzo, Italy this past summer.  It was a wonderful experience and great success!  We learned a lot about the show and subject matter while in Europe and we are excited to share a more fully realized, site specific version of the show with Bay Area audiences!
Risks &
• We are a young, small company.  As such, we are still learning a lot about how to operate, sustain ourselves, and grow. How can we have a long life as a company?

•  We believe that theatre must address the painful as well as the beautiful aspects of our society. We trust that our audiences will be excited about this challenging subject material and recognize its importance!

•  From the success of our last crowd funding campaign, we already know that we can do this with your help. We have already traveled with WE GO BOOM to Italy and back again. Now, we need your help to bring it directly to our community. Together, we can do this. 

    • Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to contribute financially, here are some other ways you can help:

    • SPREAD THE WORD: about our Company, The Show, and our fundraising campaign!
column2: >Please ask anyone and everyone to get involved in this campaign using the Indie-Go-Go share tools!

column1: • DONATE YOUR TIME: If you are excited about our company and want to get involved, we have lots for you to do!  It takes a village to make a play.

","OUR STORYWe are The Bonfire Makers,  a brand spankin' new (small, but growing) Oakland based theatre company with a big vision to bring together our diverse Bay Area community by creating theatre that directly responds to our present socio-political landscape. Our current project, WE GO BOOM, explores the impact of the tech industry on Oakland specifically. The piece examines both the tech industry's role in displacing black and brown residents and also how technology can help us create a more just and positive world.  By exploring what is happening now in our community, we ask the question:  where do we go from here? The play is a woven tapestry of interviews, personal stories, physical improvisation, and super awesome original music. The Bonfire Makers is made up of 6 performers, our awesome production team, and our magnificent Composer. We are:
Melissa Carter, Co-Founder  and performer
Sonia Decker, Co-Founder and performer
Georgina Stuart Oram, Events Coordinator and Marketing Director
Jennifer Fong, Stage Manager Alex Van Gils, Composer Our Immensely Talented Ensemble: Tierra AllenAndre San-Chez Christina Shonkwiler Sango Tajima
What We Need & What You Get Here's the Breakdown:
Budget:  $5,000
Space/ Performance Rental plus insurance= $3,552
Administrative Costs (website maintenance and administrative printing)= $123
Marketing Costs (Marketing Director stipend plus printing costs for flyers and posters)= $225
Artistic Costs (Performer stipends, costumes, and scenic elements)=$700
Other Costs (Performance Concessions, fundraising costs, and estimated taxes)=$400
If you support We Go Boom, you'll be part of the team and enjoy free tickets, recording of our original score, and more!
If we do not meet the entirety of our fundraising goal, the money that we make will go first to paying the artists and then to space rental.
If we exceed our goal, the money will go into planning for the future and deepening community relationships.
The Impact This show will create vital dialogue about the massive presence of the tech industry in the Bay Area.  Our central questions include:
Why is there a lack of diversity in the tech industry?
How can the presence of the tech industry positively benefit long time Oakland residents?
How is technology changing the way that we communicate an interact with our communities?
What positive tools does technology offer us?  How can we use technology to transform our current oppressive system?
We will have a facilitated discussion about these questions after each of our 6 performances to create community dialogue and inspire continued conversation.

We've been working on this show for over a year. Co-Founders Melissa Carter and Sonia Decker took a workshop version of We Go Boom to the CrisisArt Festival in Arezzo, Italy this past summer.  It was a wonderful experience and great success!  We learned a lot about the show and subject matter while in Europe and we are excited to share a more fully realized, site specific version of the show with Bay Area audiences!
Risks & Challenges
We are a young, small company.  As such, we are still learning a lot about how to operate, sustain ourselves, and grow. How can we have a long life as a company?

We believe that theatre must address the painful as well as the beautiful aspects of our society. We trust that our audiences will be excited about this challenging subject material and recognize its importance!

From the success of our last crowd funding campaign, we already know that we can do this with your help. We have already traveled with WE GO BOOM to Italy and back again. Now, we need your help to bring it directly to our community. Together, we can do this.     Other Ways You Can Help If you are unable to contribute financially, here are some other ways you can help:  SPREAD THE WORD: about our Company, The Show, and our fundraising campaign! Please ask anyone and everyone to get involved in this campaign using the Indie-Go-Go share tools!

About Us

Aequitas Theatre Company was set up as an alternative to typecasting or any casting based on looks. It is made up of a diverse and small group of actors who have decided to reclaim their industry and are thirsty for challenge and opportunity, reflecting their creative natures. These actors want to push the envelope, creating brave, innovative pieces of theatre with a message about society. We promote a fair and equal working environment so that our rehearsal room is a safe space.

For our next project, a double bill of Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice and Measure for Measure, we want to extend that equal environment to include a fair and equal payment for our cast and crew. We work in fringe theatre, and often the work is done on a profit-share basis, which can mean little to no pay. We want to promote a fair wage for our cast and crew and with your help, we will be able to pay everyone involved fairly, and begin a revolution of sorts in this part of the theatre industry.

About The Show

We will be putting on both Merchant of Venice and Measure for Measure with the same actors, set, venue, and rehearsal period. That's three weeks for two plays. The cast is phenomenal and the plays are being directed by Sopha Start, an incredible young director at the start of her career.

The project is still at the fundraising stage. We have been holding fundrasing events and have raised most of the money we already need for the project but rehearsals are set to begin March 2 and we need your help to get us there: we need to pay our actors and this £5,000 is all going to that.

Budget Breakdown:

Space: The wonderful Bread and Roses Theatre (www.breatdandrosestheatre.co.uk) is working with us on a split so there is no money for us to pay up front.

Props/Costumes/Set: We have an extensive costume and prop box from previous work and will be delving into that for specific items. Otherwise the look will be quite simple. This is all already provided by the company.

Rehearsal Space: £825 for three weeks. We have already raised this.

Crew: We need to pay a technician and a stage manager. We estimate around £800 for this.

Cast: We need to pay the cast minimum wage. We have a budget of £4,200 for this and this is the bulk of our fundraising.

Marketing/Promotion: The Artistic Director, Rachael Bellis, has personally paid for the marketing and promotional materials.

Tickets are already on sale: (www.breadandrosestheatre.co.uk/shakespearean-do...). This show is all ready to go ahead but we need the money to pay our actors so they can do the performance. That's where you come in and can help us!

About The Plays:

Measure For Measure :

Can you truly be yourself when you are stuck in religious conventions?

This production of Measure for Measure shows the struggle of people between being themselves and following the rules of their religion. Set in a present day Bible-Belt village in the Netherlands, people go about their everyday lives wearing a mask for the world and themselves. Their façades start to fall apart when the Duke decides to leave and give the authority over to the seemingly stern Angelo.

Merchant Of Venice:

What does it cost to fit in? To stand out?

Our version of Merchant of Venice will examine society's darker impulses. Set in the same Dutch Bible-Belt village, we explore the nastier side of one of Shakespeare's most famous plays and ask the question: what does blind faith really get you?

Who Are We?

Our company is made up of actors, directors, and writers from all over the world (we have had people from Canada, the Netherlands, the USA, Eastern Europe, and of course the UK). We have all trained or worked in the theatre for years and have learned varying techniques (The Method (Strasberg), Grotowski, Stanislavski, Hall, Viewpoints, among many others). It is the combination of these techniques and the artists that use them that produces the best work and we firmly believe that each artist's experience and training informs us as a whole.

Here are a couple of specifics:

Rachael Bellis (the Artistic Director, Co-Director Merchant of Venice): Rachael trained as an actor at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts in New York, studying Strasberg's Method for three years. Upon moving to London, she immersed herself in Shakespeare and learned the technique practiced by Sir Peter Hall, working as a student on a production of A Midsummer Night's Dream at the Rose Theatre Kingson in 2010. Rachael strongly believes in combining these techniques so that Hall's approach to text and Strasberg's approach to character work together harmoniously.

Sophia Start (Director Measure for Measure, Co-Director Merchant of Venice): Sophia has been immersed in the world of Shakespeare for much of her adult life, having studied the plays in depth at both UCL and Utrecht University in the Netherlands. She also has been a student at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, studying an evening course Directing. Sophia has assistant directed several productions on the fringe circuit and looks forward to putting that experience to work with the team at Aequitas!

Remaining Cast:

Rosie Aylward

Mark Desmond

Zoe Evans

Tara Godolphin

Rebecca Lund

Meg Matthews

The show will be performed March 24-29, 2015 at the Bread &
column2:
Roses Theatre in Clapham, an incredible new theatre space with the same desire to ensure that those who work on the fringe get proper pay. Check them out at www.breadandrosestheatre.co.uk

All money raised here will be going towards cast and crew wages. Other production costs have a budget elsewhere and are already covered. This includes the cost of Indiegogo perks, which are being funded by our artistic director, Rachael Bellis. This campaign is really all about wages for our actors and crew who really deserve to be able to earn a living from all their hard work.

Be A Patron Of The Arts

We want to put on two of the most classic of plays in one of the most classic performance styles (repertory) in what we think is the classiest city in the world. It's super important that even with budget cuts in arts funding worldwide, we continue to support and recognize the arts, whether that is in budding theatre companies like ours or elsewhere (though obviously we want you to support us...that's why we are crowdfunding).

Our project is valuable to the world because we want to show our community that we can put on performances and pay people fairly--and that message extends not only to theatre companies, but also to other companies across the world.

Our project is valuable to you (yes you!) because you will be helping people who normally work a second job to pay for their first job (aka theatre makers) to focus entirely on creating their art--which will make the work better. There is a long tradition in the arts of patrons supporting artists and if you support us, we will consider you our patron. Think about going to work and telling your colleagues you are a patron of the arts. How prestigious does that sound? (We like the sound of that too.)

We successfully put on Black Sunday, our last production in the Camden Fringe, a couple of years ago. It was successful as fringe productions go, but the profits did not make enough to pay for more than the cast and crew to celebrate at the end of the run. We want to take it further this time and ensure that a fair wage is paid to everyone. We are repeating this a lot, we know. It's because it's really important.

What If You Can't Contribute?

If you can't afford to contribute, don't worry, you can still help us!

You can share our link or our video. You can like us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/AequitasTheatre) and follow us on Twitter (@AequitasTheatre). You can share our posts. You can make noise about our campaign.

Hopefully our campaign strikes a chord with you. If it does, please donate and share so that anyone you know who you think will be able to help can do so. We've got a small amount of time (3 weeks) to make a very big change.

The Company...
The New Natives is an emerging New York City-based theatre company which focuses on producing new work by emerging artists.
column2: >Formed by Charly Clive and Jillian Geurts in 2015, The New Natives believes in making theatre for the people… contemporary,
column3: >thought-provoking work that's funny, sad and everything in between - work that challenges audiences and is accessible to all!

column1: The Play...

“The First Man” by Wil Hart is a new play receiving its premiere at Under St Marks, in Manhattan’s Lower East Side.  The play, directed by Michael Bradshaw Flynn, dives into the lives of three people at three different moments in time, as their world’s collide, shatter and get pieced back together.  It examines cycles of the human experience, wrestling with themes of power, love, sex, religion and the not-knowing.  It’s a visceral and darkly comic exchange between actors and audience, not for the faint-hearted but definitely a fascinating night at the theatre.

The production will run September 1st - 4th 2016 at Under St Marks Theatre in St Marks Place, NY. 

Who We Are...
We are a small group of in-demand American and International artists.
Our playwright is Minnesota-born Wil Hart.
Our director is Michael Bradshaw Flynn, who is also the current Artistic Director of the Scranton Shakespeare Festival.

Our three actors, Jillian Geurts, Dash Barber and Dan Newsome each take on three roles within the three worlds of the play.  They are all graduates of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts and are building solid careers in the industry, working across the board in theatre, film and television.

column1: Venue - $1500.00
Your Help...

No donation or act of support is too small! 

Supporting ""The First Man"" and helping us meet our goal will mean we can create a show of the highest quality.  A show that we believe audiences should see.

Even the smallest amount will help make this show a reality, and all donations are greatly appreciated. We have some great perks that we hope you'll enjoy!

Presentación

 ESPAÑOL
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Este proyecto es el sueño de 12 chicos de edades entre 20 y 25 años en su mayoría, que dedican su vida al baile.

column3: >Street Squad se creó en 2012 con la idea de juntar el talento de una serie de muchachos a los cuales les apasiona la danza urbana. Desde su creación han trabajado muy duro para conseguir además de mejorar como bailarines individuales, hacerlo como grupo de baile, ensayando miles de horas para coordinar los movimientos más asombrosos.

column1: <span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Su trayectoria es increíble puesto que desde que empezaron a competir han sido muy diferentes al resto de grupos y han ganado grandes premios. El año pasado Street Squad se clasificó para representar España en el campeonato del mundo ""Hip Hop International"", desgraciadamente este campeonato se celebraba en San Diego y para ellos fue económicamente imposible ir a competir y, lo más importante, poder mostrar y medir su talento ante grupos de todo el mundo. Después de acariciar un sueño grandioso para cualquier bailarín de danza urbana, tuvieron que resignarse y quedarse en España. Tras este mazazo siguieron trabajando, soñando con la oportunidad de volver a conseguir algo tan difícil como es clasificarse para un mundial... Vieron una posibilidad cuando se enteraron del casting de ""Insuperables"" de TVE, se presentaron, fueron seleccionados, concursaron en este novedoso Talent Show en el cual había en juego 30.000€. No se lo pensaron dos veces: ""si ganamos utilizaremos el premio para poder competir en un mundial"", un sueño muy fantasioso, pues no solo es el dinero, es volverse a clasificar... algo a lo que pocos pueden aspirar.
column3: >De nuevo rozaron el sueño con la punta de sus dedos, quedaron superfinalistas de Insuperables, pero no ganaron el premio.

>Este año 2016 han empezado muy fuerte: Primero se clasifican para una final Europea de Danza Urbana en Bélgica, viajan en 2 auto caravanas para poder costearse el viaje, pues son un grupo de familias humildes. Que grande es su alegría cuando ganan en Bélgica la final Europea de World Of Dance, uno de los campeonatos mas importantes del mundo, algo que no se habían ni planteado. Pero de nuevo se encuentran en la misma situación que hace un año... La final mundial es en Los Angeles, el 30 de Julio de 2016. 12 muchachos que se esfuerzan a diario para llegar a un sueño que pocos pueden conseguir. Siendo campeones de Europa de nuevo el destino es tan inalcanzable económicamente como lo fue hace un año, pero esta vez no van a dejar de luchar.
column5: >Esta vez han creado este proyecto ""Street Squad Road to LA"" para pedir ayuda y poder conseguir algo por lo que llevan luchando tantos años: Estar en el campeonato del mundo, representar España y medirse contra los mejores del planeta. Ellos harán todo lo que esté en su mano para conseguir esa ayuda, para poder lograr algo tan grande. De esto trata este proyecto, de no dejar que el talento se pierda por falta de medios, de no dejar que los sueños se trunquen por no ser de familias adineradas, porque todos tenemos derecho a soñar, pero si nos permitimos hacerlo tenemos la obligación de luchar por esos sueños. Buscamos sponsors, colaboradores, ayuda de gente a la que le guste nuestro trabajo, todas las formas de ayuda serán bienvenidas.
column6:
>Puedes ver más sobre nuestro trabajo en Galería, donde verás varios videos.

 ENGLISH

column1:
This project is the dream of 12 people aged from 20 to 25 (most of all) who dedicate their life to dancing. Street Squad was created in 2012 aiming to gather the skills of different boys which enjoyed very much urban dancing. Since the creation, they all have worked a lot and very hard to improve as individual dancers and as a group. They have had to practise during lots of hours to coordinate their most awesome movements.

Their career is impressive. Since they started compiting, they have diferentiate from others, creating a personal and unique style, and achiving enormous victories. Last year Street Squad was classified to represent Spain in the world championship of Hip Hop International. This championship takes place in San Diego but. unfortunatelly, it was impossible for Street Squad to travel there because of the high cost of it. They lost the oportunity to show their talent and size each other up with groups from all around the world. After caressing that big dream, they had to give up and stay in Spain. After this setback, they kept on working, hoping to have another opportunity like that in the future... The next year, they had another opportunity when they heard about the auditions for Insuperables (a spanish talent tv show). They assisted the auditions, they were classified and they aimed for 30.000 (the final prize). They didn't think about it twice: if we win the prize, we will use it to compete in a world championship. A very unrealistic dream, since it meant they had to win the tlaent show plus classify again in the Hip Hop Internation Spain Qualifiers, something to which few groups can aspire. Again, they caressed their dream: they were superfinalists of the program, but they didn't win the prize.

This year 2016, they have started stronger than ever. First, they were classified for an european final of urban dancing in Belgium (WOD). They traveled with 2 caravans in order to cut down on costs (they all belong to modest families). And their happiness was so extreme when they won the Europe finals of World Of Dance in Belgium... One of the most important championships in the world, something that they couldn't have ever imagined. But again, they have the same problem: the finals take place in Los Angeles, on the 30th of July (2016). 12 boys that make enormous efforts day by day to achieve a dream that few people are capable to achieve. This final in Los Angeles is as unattainable as it was one year ago, but this time they won't stop fighting.

This time, they have created the project ""Street Squad Road To LA"" to ask for help. To ask for people's involvement in this dream they have been fighting for. To be in LA representing Spain in the World of Dance championship and compete with the bst groups of the planet... They will do all they can to obtain that help, to achieve something enormous. This is what this project is about. A lack of means should not be a barrier to talent. Dreams should not belong only to wealthy families. Because every single person has the right to dream BUT, if we let us dream, we have to fight for those dreams. We are looking for sponsors, colaborators, help from people who likes our work and worries about our cause. All kind of help will be welcome.
You can see more about our work in Gallery.

 
 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

 

A todo aquel que haya contribuido se le mencionará en un vídeo agradecimiento que realizaremos al final del proyecto. Y todo el mundo podrá disfrutar de nuestro viaje en vídeo en youtube.

Ademas, para todas aquellas colaboraciones igual o superiores a 10€, obtendrás una recompensa extra! Desde tu mención en nuestro festival hasta merchandising exclusivo del proyecto ""street Squad road to LA"". Para mas detalles sobre estas recompensas echad un vistazo al lateral superior derecho de esta misma pagina.
Recuerda!! puedes donar la cantidad que desees, desde céntimos hasta el monto total de 30.000€.
Riesgos y desafíos

Este proyecto no tiene apenas obstáculos posibles, es la financiación de un viaje, los únicos obstáculos que podrían surgir serían problemas con los  vuelos, los cuales se solventarían con la contratación un seguro para que cualquier incidencia en los vuelos se solucionen con la compañía aérea y el seguro, sin que el grupo pueda perder la oportunidad de viajar.
En el caso de que por fuerza mayor el evento puediese cancelarse, se utilizaría la recaudación para ir cuando vuelva a celebrarse.
Son casos muy hipotéticos que no es normal que ocurran. Pueden ver la profesionalidad y seriedad del evento en http://www.worldofdance.com/
Es un evento totalmente afianzado que lleva muchos años de recorrido y eliminatorias por todo el mundo que no se suspendería a no ser que fuese por una fuerza mayor.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

 

Ademas de las donaciones a nuestro proyecto, puedes ayudarnos siguiéndonos en nuestra pagina de facebook https://www.facebook.com/streetsquadoficial y compartiendo este proyecto para llegar a mas gente.
Cabe decir que también vendemos merchandising del grupo y calendarios propios que puedes ver también en nuestro facebook.
","Presentación ESPAÑOL
Este proyecto es el sueño de 12 chicos de edades entre 20 y 25 años en su mayoría, que dedican su vida al baile.

Street Squad se creó en 2012 con la idea de juntar el talento de una serie de muchachos a los cuales les apasiona la danza urbana. Desde su creación han trabajado muy duro para conseguir además de mejorar como bailarines individuales, hacerlo como grupo de baile, ensayando miles de horas para coordinar los movimientos más asombrosos.

Su trayectoria es increíble puesto que desde que empezaron a competir han sido muy diferentes al resto de grupos y han ganado grandes premios. El año pasado Street Squad se clasificó para representar España en el campeonato del mundo ""Hip Hop International"", desgraciadamente este campeonato se celebraba en San Diego y para ellos fue económicamente imposible ir a competir y, lo más importante, poder mostrar y medir su talento ante grupos de todo el mundo. Después de acariciar un sueño grandioso para cualquier bailarín de danza urbana, tuvieron que resignarse y quedarse en España. Tras este mazazo siguieron trabajando, soñando con la oportunidad de volver a conseguir algo tan difícil como es clasificarse para un mundial... Vieron una posibilidad cuando se enteraron del casting de ""Insuperables"" de TVE, se presentaron, fueron seleccionados, concursaron en este novedoso Talent Show en el cual había en juego 30.000€. No se lo pensaron dos veces: ""si ganamos utilizaremos el premio para poder competir en un mundial"", un sueño muy fantasioso, pues no solo es el dinero, es volverse a clasificar... algo a lo que pocos pueden aspirar.De nuevo rozaron el sueño con la punta de sus dedos, quedaron superfinalistas de Insuperables, pero no ganaron el premio.

Este año 2016 han empezado muy fuerte: Primero se clasifican para una final Europea de Danza Urbana en Bélgica, viajan en 2 auto caravanas para poder costearse el viaje, pues son un grupo de familias humildes. Que grande es su alegría cuando ganan en Bélgica la final Europea de World Of Dance, uno de los campeonatos mas importantes del mundo, algo que no se habían ni planteado. Pero de nuevo se encuentran en la misma situación que hace un año... La final mundial es en Los Angeles, el 30 de Julio de 2016. 12 muchachos que se esfuerzan a diario para llegar a un sueño que pocos pueden conseguir. Siendo campeones de Europa de nuevo el destino es tan inalcanzable económicamente como lo fue hace un año, pero esta vez no van a dejar de luchar.Esta vez han creado este proyecto ""Street Squad Road to LA"" para pedir ayuda y poder conseguir algo por lo que llevan luchando tantos años: Estar en el campeonato del mundo, representar España y medirse contra los mejores del planeta. Ellos harán todo lo que esté en su mano para conseguir esa ayuda, para poder lograr algo tan grande. De esto trata este proyecto, de no dejar que el talento se pierda por falta de medios, de no dejar que los sueños se trunquen por no ser de familias adineradas, porque todos tenemos derecho a soñar, pero si nos permitimos hacerlo tenemos la obligación de luchar por esos sueños. Buscamos sponsors, colaboradores, ayuda de gente a la que le guste nuestro trabajo, todas las formas de ayuda serán bienvenidas.Puedes ver más sobre nuestro trabajo en Galería, donde verás varios videos. ENGLISH

Short Summary

My name is Patrick-Jude Oteh and I am the Artistic Director of the Jos Repertory Theatre. We use the theatre to challenge crucial issues that affect our daily existence.

The highlight of my career happened in 2009 - 2011 when I was fortunate to spend three summers at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington DC. I left the program learning how to use the arts to produce change.

Our current campaign is critical to us as we are confronted with dire situations that defy all economic indices but I believe very firmly that the arts can help point our legion of unemployed youths and even in-school youths in the right direction towards making life changing career judgements.
Every single contribution will help in making this reality possible using the arts of the theatre. Poverty is a daily grind we believe we can use the arts to challenge and possibly change.
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We are requesting for USD $25,000 as our total funds to enable us create undocumented stories from very ordinary lives which are being lived under very daunting and extra-ordinary circumstances. Most of these stories are very brave and universal.

column1: BUDGET:
Design USD $3,500
Overheads including expansion of our current space USD $8,000
Publicity towards the 10th Jos Festival of Theatre 2017 USD $3,500
Artistes Fees / Honorarium USD $10,000
TOTAL USD $25,000
If we do not reach our entire goal, we will scale down the scope of our project or make another appeal through local philanthropists to make up for the difference.
The Impact

Our project is very valuable and will make the much needed difference in our immediate community. Currently, there are over 15 million young people with no access to a hope filled  and bright future. We believe that the theatre can make a difference.
There are about 10 million young people that are out of school in the region where we work. We believe that the arts can make a difference in their situation.

There are over 7 million in-school youths who have not been able to make a decision on which life changing career they will want to go into. We believe that the theatre can help them to make a decision.
Your contribution will make this possible!
Risks &

We have been in existence for 17 years and we are still energized to be around for a long time to come. Our ability to be resilient has been of immense value in our situation and the life changing benefits of the arts and the theatre specifically will continue to enable us to make a difference in the immediate future.

The challenges are numerous but they are not insurmountable. We have the will, and we have the ability and our young people have the energy but they need a platform. The stage and the theatre can provide this platform.
Other Ways You Can Help
Help us to spread the word to your networks and your contacts!
Join us to make a difference using the arts of the theatre!!!

Live Girls! joins forces with A Contemporary Theatre

In July of 2016, Live Girls! will collaborate with ActLab to present the world premiere of “Things You Can Do” in Seattle, WA.  This unique opportunity allows us to bring a new work by a female playwright  to a fresh audience with the support of one of Seattle’s most exciting and innovative theatres.


What is “Things You Can Do” about?

A drunken kiss, an icy plunge,a reckless act of revenge.

Playwright Kristen Palmer takes on the issue of global climate change through the lens of a family on the verge of a meltdown. Brilliant scientist Stevie returns home in the midst of a devastating personal crisis, only to find her family members frozen in isolation and her hometown losing its footing. Emergency actions are taken that threaten this tiny and fragile ecosystem.


Why do we need help?

This an ambitious project for our tiny company, and our artists are dedicating significant time to the project.  With the support of 4Culture, our generous supporters, and ACT, we have secured funds to cover our production expenses, travel for the playwright’s first workshop visit, and a tiny stipend for each artist. All of the core staff of Live Girls! are volunteers, and we have  pledged to work toward more compensation for our artists who put hundreds of hours into each production.  All donations to this campaign will go directly to artist stipends and travel reimbursement for our playwright.  


What do  Live Girls do?

Live Girls! is one of the longest running fringe theater companies in Seattle. We have been dedicated to producing and developing new plays by women since 1999.  We have supported the creation of more than 300 theatrical works by women in our 16 year history, as well as supported hundreds of female performers in multiple disciplines including music, dance, comedy and improv, through our cabaret and performance series.  We are an Associated Program of Shunpike, a 501(c)(3) non- profit,  whichmakes all donations to us tax-deductible!


Where will this money go?

All donations to this campaign will go directly to artist stipends and travel reimbursement for our playwright.  None of the funds from this campaign will go to ANY admin or other material expenses.  Live Girls! has even budgeted to cover the fees relating to this campaign (minus the mailing of perks if you choose them).  We repeat, all money goes directly to the artists on this project! We have chosen flexible funding, so whatever we raise will go to the artists on the following schedule:


$500 raised for playwright rehearsal travel

$1900 raised adds $100 to all artist stipends

$2400 raised for playwright opening weekend travel

$3800 raised adds an additional $100 to all artist stipends

$5200 raised adds an additional $100 to all artist stipends


Why is supporting Live Girls! important?

Here is what our artists have said:

“I have worked with Live Girls! as both director and emerging playwright. They have helped me forge relationships that would not have been possible without their commitment to the work of women.  Live Girls! has created a network of women artists that extends further each year that nurtures and excites our artistic visions in the theater community. “

Jennifer Jasper- Playwright, Producer, Solo Performer


“Live Girls has been incredibly important in my development as an artist. They provide opportunities that are sorely lacking for women within the arts community. They have fostered a sense of confidence and purpose in me and, as a result, I am now producing work of a scale that I never would have dreamed of before.“


Isabella de Campos- Playwright and Writer/Producer of Northern Belles Web Series


“What keeps me coming back to work with LG! is their commitment to creating opportunities for women artists to do what they do best. One of the ways that LG! sets itself apart from other theater companies is their championing and development of new works.  And above all else, Live Girls! creates an inviting and welcoming community where we are pushed to be the artists we are.”


May Nquyen- Playwright, Producer (Pork Filled Productions) Performer


Live Girls Theater commits to the plays they love by making space, bringing together theater artists and supporting the development of new work with open-hearted generosity and a tenacious commitment to the work.  This is a treasure. ”

Kristin Palmer- Playwright and Artistic Director of Oddfellow Playhouse


Can’t donate but still want to help?

Please share this campaign with others!

Spread the word about the show by sharing our facebook event- https://www.facebook.com/events/1578613052466749/

Buy a ticket now!

http://www.acttheatre.org/Tickets/OnStage/ThingsYouCanDo

Short Summary
Thank you so much for checking out our project! Below are a few things about the play and me, the producer to give you a little feel of what you're getting yourself into.

I'm a filmmaker, actor and writer, now trying my lot at producing my first play. I recently went to Cannes Film Festival Short Corner with a short film I made about FGM and continue to make art in whatever form I can, highlighting female and human issues around the globe.

‘Daddy was a Boogie Man’ is a play about a dysfunctional relationship between a mother and her daughter and the outside world. Set in 1970’s Dublin, in a tenement block, Mammy and her seventeen year old daughter, Eadaoin live together in a cramped and filthy room.  This show will employ physical theatre and at the same time be heavily reliant on the strong dialogue and powerful words. It is moving and emotional because of the tragic situation
column2: their relationship is based on love, no matter how dysfunctional. It is also very much a feminist play with strong female characters questioning what it means to be a woman and what one’s role is in a social and religious context.

column1: We are needing to fundraise to get 12 cast and crew to Galway Fringe between July 11th and 16th, as well as funding for our props and set.
In order to do this we'll be holding some fundraising events, but most of all we'll rely on online contributions from art and theatre lovers around the world!

Be sure to click on 'Back It' if you just want to contribute. If you would like rewards, make sure you scroll down along the rewards tab and click on 'Get This Perk' :) 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get
  • Most funding will be going into transporting the cast and crew to Galway, as well as the accommodation there.
  • Rewards will be given to each person who contributes, each reward varies depending on how much is given.

column1:
• Reward examples: Social media shoutouts, show tickets, signed posters.

    • The Impact

    Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

    • Daddy Was a Boogie Man is an important story we're passionate about telling and believe it will have a great impact on the way female on female domestic violence is viewed. We hope to share our passions of telling this story with as wide an audience as we can, and you can help with that!

    Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Putting on a show like this always comes with challenges as simple as finding accommodation and doing enough marketing, but with your support we'll be able to surmount these.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

If you haven't any means to contribute we totally understand!
Even just sharing this page and spreading the word about this project is contribution so we'd be bountifully grateful :)

We hope to share our passions of telling this story with as wide an audience as we can, and you can help with that!    Risks & Challenges Putting on a show like this always comes with challenges as simple as finding accommodation and doing enough marketing, but with your support we'll be able to surmount these.
Other Ways You Can Help If you haven't any means to contribute we totally understand!
Even just sharing this page and spreading the word about this project is contribution so we'd be bountifully grateful :)",0.0,0,"3 Campaigns
|","Dublin, Ireland",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/daddy-was-a-boogie-man-goes-to-galway-fringe/pica

In March 2017, Bated Breath will transport New York audiences into the “white-hot” core of the fine art auction market. The audience gets play money, paddles, and bids on real works of art. The narrative follows the biography of a painting from creation to auction and is based on true stories from auction world insiders. Art world legends vie for wealth and immortality in power plays that have thrust the art market into the global spotlight. Using sound, movement, video projections, audience interactivity and more props than you can shake an intern’s broom at, the play gives the audience a unforgettable inside look at the only market — besides the stock market — to show up on the front pages of every major newspaper: the art market.
We need your help

We need to raise $10,000 to cover basic production expenses like actors, designers, transportation, costumes and set materials. Part of Bated Breath’s model is to make theatre on a shoestring budget and make it look grand. The truth is, we have never hired a professional design team to work on our shows. But working at this level in New York means we have to go beyond grand to extraordinary. We know that  you are going to be BLOWN AWAY when you come to the show. You will experience something unlike anything else you've seen. No one’s ever done a play quite like this before, mixing audience interaction, docudrama and physical theatre to explore an important subject that’s given rise to countless articles and books. Bated Breath can’t wait to share Beneath the Gavel with you. Please help us make this play everything we know it will be.

Thank you for your consideration.
